story:
My Situation

While repairing a broadcast transmitter in 1991, I received a shock of nearly 8000 volts.  It left me with a mild traumatic brain injury (TBI), chronic pain, frequent severe migraine headaches, and short-term memory impairment.

It took almost 6 years to be diagnosed with the brain injury.  My teeth died right away and we spend about 2 years reconstructing my jaw and placing dental implants.  This was after 27 root-canal treatments that failed.  I hit a very deep depression and finally I attempted suicide to escape the physical and emotional pain.  It was right after my attempt that my TBI was diagnosed.

Professionals began my rehab as soon as I was stable after my attempt.  My pain is controlled now, and I believe I need to keep helping other survivors to give back much of what I've been blessed with as far as knowledge and ways to compensate.

Here's What Your Help Will Provide

By making a donation, you'll help defray the cost of providing education to the public, employers and families of a TBI survivor.  You'll also be helping survivors directly through your donation, as it will allow me to continue to travel to survivors and work with them to help them achieve the independence they want and need.  We survivors merely want to live as normal life as possible.  Not only will your donation help get them the services they want and need, it will let them know others do care.  To date, I've been funding the programming and services out of my own pocket, but it's time to expand and have the ability to provide to more survivors.  In addition, we're setting up a video production studio so that we may produce high quality educational videos for TBI survivors, their families, and the general public.  These videos will be at no cost to survivors and their families.

The Ultimate Goal

Most survivors who are able, want to return to work and be a productive member of society.  I was encouraged to go on disability, but I'm able to work, and believe I should be self-supporting.  Most other survivors feel the same way.  Your generosity will enable me to spend more time helping others who have sustained and survived a traumatic brain injury.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, here are some ways you can be just as helpful:

  • Share my story and my campaign with as many people as possible, using Indiegogo share tools;
  • Donate office supplies and other necessities as the need arises

Thank you so much for taking the time to help support the education mission!

story:
My Story

Hi there, folks. My name is Yevette, and with your help, someday I will change the face of the fashion industry. 

I am a senior at the University of St. Thomas in St. Paul, MN. I am studying entrepreneurial business, apparel design, and studio art; and this upcoming spring is my senior fashion show at St. Catherine's University. We present our own line of 7-10 full looks, each garment handmade by the designer. I take great pride in my work and hold myself to high standards: I use eco-friendly and socially responsible materials; I recycle fabrics to give them new life; and I employ as many couture techniques as possible.

It is not cheap to create beautiful, socially-responsible clothing, especially when you do not have the option of buying wholesale-- that's right, our whole line is out-of-pocket. One simple dress worth of fabric can be $50, easy. Furthermore, design (and college in general) has a knack for taking up your whole life, to the point where one can only work a few hours a week. Thus, here is a typical broke college kid. I am also a transfer at UST (a private institution), so all of my previous scholarships went null and they offered me nothing in return. My parents try to assist me after MN grants and scholarships, but gym teachers and woodworkers do not hold the most glamorous of jobs in today's economy. So, perhaps you see my predicament: I can barely pay for tuition and loans as is. Any contribution will help me so much-- know that you will be fostering education and creativity.


The Impact

I transferred schools very abruptly because I had a dream. I want to run a business that offers fair trade clothing in the US; that helps entire communities in the East or Africa; that gives back to those in need; and in turn, one that allows the buyer to know they have made the world a happier place while looking quite dapper.

Please help me realize this goal. It starts with my senior line. I promise you that this line, with your contribution, will help launch me into the business and fashion world, where I will fight to make a difference.

If I cannot find financial help to buy fabric, I will either (A) not be able to present this year; or (B) have to push myself much further into debt and not be able to create my visions. Please consider a contribution.


What I Need & What You Get

I am simply hoping for the funds to buy materials for my senior collection, which should be somewhere between $600 and $700 because I create full gowns and other garments made from natural fiber textiles (fair trade, when possible), some of which will be hand-dyed. Materials refers to fashion-fabric, thread, closures, interior support textiles, and beading. I would be happy to share my vision with whomever is interested.

This is my only possible funding source right now. Any amount will help!

There are quaint benefits (other than that wonderful warm-n-fuzzy feeling) for you lovely people who would like to pitch in, as seen in the "perks" section.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support me in this campaign, all I can ask is that you consider buying more socially responsible, eco-friendly, and Fair Trade certified products in the future. Think of where your items are coming from-- think of who made it and under what conditions. Together we can change the face of the fashion industry.

story:
UPDATE-- If you feel more comfortable sending a check, that's great too! Contributions in any form are much appreciated. You can mail it to:

549 West 123rd St. #2D NY, NY 10027

___________________________________________________________________

Two of my dreams are to work with ESL students and to become fluent in Spanish. Teaching with the Village Education Project in Ecuador can help me immeasurably towards my personal goals, as well as create a vibrant and enriching educational atmosphere for under-served students. I'm reaching out to my friends, family, and community for support in order to make this a reality.

DESCRIPTION OF THE ORGANIZATION

The Village Education Project is a non-profit that supports educaton for students in the highlands outside of Otavalo. Due to the high cost of schools' matriculation fees, uniforms and books, only 1 in 10 students in the impoverished rural areas receive a high school education. The Village Education Project provides full scholarships for students as well as tutoring during the school year, but this is not enough. Many are not adequately prepared to succeed in high school. That's where volunteers come in!

VOLUNTEERS' ROLE

Each summer, volunteers help catch the students up in the areas where they need it most: English, math, and computer skills. (I'd teach English, because I'm a big fan of the language, and because the students may surpass me in math/comp sci.) The curriculum has been prepared by Ecuadorian educators who train the volunteers and coordinate the program on the ground, so the lessons are consistent with what the students will learn when they start high school.

WHAT THE FUNDING IS FOR

Volunteers also help The Village Education Project fund the students' scholarships. Each volunteer is required to raise a minimum of $500, and 100% of this money goes towards paying for the students to attend high school. It costs only $200 to send one student to high school per year!

In addition to the $500, I need to raise money for my flight (~$1000) and living expenses (~$1000). If I can exceed my goal, I'll have more money to go towards contribution to student scholarships.

I'm immensely grateful for donations of any size. If you have any questions, please e-mail me at rbranson@oberlin.edu. ¡Muchísimas gracias!

Love,

Rena

story:
Video in Deutsch

Deutsch

What are our aims?

Many memorial ceremonies have taken place in connection with the 80th anniversary of the seizure of power by the Nazis in Germany. Memorials have been erected, exhibitions initiated, a wide variety of information is available. These are historically and scientifically correct, but in our view the individual human fates are paid too little attention.

This is precisely what we want to change with our project. Getting to know the victims personally extends the historical facts to make a human experience.

 

How will we achieve this?

By means of the mobile internet we want to resurrect the biographies of persecuted people directly where they happened. Personal documents such as pictures, texts or letters, any available sound or film recordings can be retrieved by smartphone or tablet computer spontaneously directly at the scene. The memories of these people could not be kept more vividly.

We want to show that the exclusion, arrests, deportations, and crimes did and do not take place "somewhere", but in our very midst. Maybe just around the corner or a few streets away. One of our central concerns is to establish this link. We want to bring the information out of books and exhibitions back into life and thus raise awareness for more tolerance in dealing with each other.

 

Why do we need money?

The money is to cover the costs of research, operation of the technical infrastructure (servers, software), any necessary licenses, printing of information material and communication with authorities, museums, universities and other organisations.

Specifically, the money should finance the first phase of the project. For the implementation of the project the agency 200grad has founded the association "No future without a past". We would like to begin in Berlin with its three large memorials to the victims of the Holocaust, Sinti and Roma and homosexuals. Here we want to represent as many biographies as possible at the places where the victims lived. When this aim is achieved we intend to expand our project throughout Germany and Europe.

 

Every day people still suffer discrimination, intimidation and persecution. If you take the same view as we do, that people should share knowledge and communicate in order to learn from history and to shape a better future together, then please support our project.

 

 

 

English

Was wollen wir tun?

Eine Vielzahl von Gedenkfeiern fanden im Zusammenhang mit dem 80. Jahrestag der Machtergreifung der Nationalsozialisten in Deutschland statt. Mahnmale wurden errichtet, Ausstellungen initiiert, eine Vielzahl von Informationen steht zur Verfügung. Diese sind historisch und wissenschaftlich korrekt, in unseren Augen kommen dabei aber die persönlichen Schicksale der Menschen zu kurz.

Genau dies wollen wir mit unserem Projekt ändern. Gerade das persönliche Kennenlernen der Opfer erweitert die historischen Fakten hin zu einem menschlichen Erleben und Erfühlen.

 

Wie wollen wir das erreichen?

Mit Hilfe des mobilen Internets wollen wir die Lebensgeschichten der verfolgten Menschen direkt „vor Ort“ wieder zum Leben erwecken. Persönliche Bilder, Texte oder Briefe, eventuell vorhandene Ton- oder Filmaufnahmen können so über jedes Smartphone oder Tablet ganz spontan direkt am Ort des Geschehens abgerufen werden. Lebendiger kann man die Erinnerung an diese Menschen nicht bewahren.

Wir wollen zeigen, dass die Ausgrenzungen, Verhaftungen, Deportationen und Verbrechen nicht „irgendwo“, sondern mitten unter uns stattfanden und -finden. Vielleicht gerade um die Ecke oder ein paar Straßen weiter. Diesen Bezug herzustellen ist eines unserer zentralen Anliegen. Wir wollen die Informationen aus den Büchern und Ausstellungen zurück ins Leben holen und damit ein Bewusstsein für mehr Toleranz im Umgang miteinander schaffen.

 

Wofür benötigen wir das Geld?

Mit dem Geld werden die Kosten für Recherche, Betrieb der technischen Infrastruktur (Server, Software), eventuell notwendige Lizenzen, Druck von Infomaterial und Kommunikation mit Behörden, Museen, Universitäten und anderen Organisationen gedeckt.

Konkret ist mit dem Geld die Finanzierung der ersten Projektphase vorgesehen. Zur Durchführung des Projektes wurde auf Initiative der Agentur 200grad der Verein "Keine Zukunft ohne Vergangenheit" gegründet. Starten möchten wir in Berlin mit seinen drei großen Mahnmalen für die Opfer des Holocaust, Sinti und Roma und Homosexuellen. Hier wollen wir so viele Biografien wie möglich an den Wohn- und Lebensorten der Opfer darstellen. Wenn dieses Ziel erreicht ist, wollen wir unser Projekt deutschland- und europaweit ausbauen.

 

Immer noch werden täglich Menschen diskriminiert, eingeschüchtert und ausgegrenzt. Wenn Sie wie wir der Meinung sind, dass Menschen sich austauschen und Wissen gemeinsam nutzen sollten, um aus der Geschichte zu lernen und dadurch die Zukunft gemeinsam und besser zu gestalten, dann unterstützen Sie unser Projekt.

story:
I am a grandmother who has been traveling to Africa for 20 years as a wildlife photographer.

While there in 2005 I developed a friendship with a Maasai guide from Kenya,named Wilson Lolpapit..

He had just opened the first school in his remote home area of Loita Hills, and what he accomplished inspired me.

We remained in contact and on my 60th birthday I decided to give 1 year of my life to help these wonderful people get a few basic things we take for granted every day and which will greatly  improve their lives.

I  moved into a Maasai home and live without any of the things most people take for granted.

We have No water, no power, and very limited food, I milk cows,I fetch firewood…I live as a Maasai.

My posts on Facebook reconnected me with a friend from high school, Karen Keilt, and she offered to help me with my project.

Karen is the author of "the Parrots Perch"  and a successful business woman with fundraising background.

Together , we grandmothers, want to make a difference in the lives of these children.

They need light to study in their quest for a brighter futures.

There are now a total of 21 schools in the Loita Hills area of the Rift Valley with a total of 7200 students.  

Our first goal is to raise  funds to provide solar lights to the all 300 students attending Ilkujuka Primary School.
These kids are eager to learn and improve their lives. The children walk upwards of 15 km a day and go without shoes and in many cases , and even without food in order to buy their required uniforms and pay the tuition.

Many of the students actually sleep on the classroom floor during the school week to avoid the dangers of walking home through the bush after dark. Their schools have no electricity, light or water. They receive no financial assistance and very few resources or supplies from the government. Today  a word for school in their Maasai language doesn't exist.

As one of the oldest cultures in the world, the Maasai people have always lived a nomadic life. Until recently, no one possessed anything more than a few cows, a few sheep and goats.

That is all changing. Though they still reside in homes made of cow dung, these homes are now permanent. Families that can, have begun agriculture. Various church organizations have helped build a few classrooms that are now their schools.

The students devour their lessons. I has never met children with more desire to learn. They cannot do homework or read at home because they have no light.

They work by wood burning fires at home and the occasional flashlight when sleeping at the school—but wood and batteries are both valuable commodities.

With our plan EVERY student will OWN their light. It will be used at home as well as late nights in the classroom. The lights will become an incentive to send a child to school. Families with more than one child attending school will benefit greatly since these lights will be shared among these large family villages. They will create a much safer home environment because at present, very few can even afford flashlights.

We are purchasing solar lights  for $10.00 each.

My pledge is to  personally hand out each light to every student.

Every dollar will go directly to purchasing lights…there will be no administrative costs.

We will do this one school at a time and soon the Rift Valley will shine..THANKS TO YOU!  Won't you please help light a life?

As a special thank you for supporting us, we will send you an African wildlife print!

story:
Imagine

15 MBA students from one of the oldest HBCU's to offer MBA degrees trekking through the ancient cities of Beijing and Shanghai, exploring the fundamentals of international business.

 

 

Picture

Your experience in graduate school. The friends you met. The lessons you learned inside and outside of the classroom. The times you've spent traveling abroad, or dreaming of traveling abroad.

What We Need 

We need $75,000 to send 15 students to China. Students will study International Business and Doing Business in China. We will learn how to conduct business in China, which will enable us to become better informed global leaders. As of now, we are starting with $25,000 on Indiegogo, but our MAIN GOAL is $75,000. PLEASE help us reach OUR GOAL! 

In the event we don't reach our goal, ALL funds will go toward students expenses for the China trip. These funds will help defray the costs of airfare, tuition, housing, and fees.

The Impact

MBA students are groomed to become world leaders. Programs such as CAU’s help to enrich the minds of rising stars through education and exposure. Through your generous contribution, our class will have an invaluable opportunity to travel to a dynamic and powerful country to learn about international business. As tomorrow’s leaders, the potential span of our influence is broad and our preparedness to take on the global arena is critical.

What You Get

Your funds help ensure that future business leaders are prepared to succeed in a global economy. You benefit by helping propel these rising stars to the next level in their careers. Besides a happy go lucky feeling inside, check out the perks you'll get by supporting our campaign!

Other Ways You Can Help

Share our link with all your colleagues, associates, and friends. Send out an email to everyone you know and harness the power of social media to share our campaign! We thank you in advance. 

~Clark Atlanta University MBA Class of 2014

story:
Quick Facts:

$10 - provides a family of 4 with food that lasts a months

$.46 - pays for a home visit from Pallium India and medications

$27.37 - pays for a whole day of in home care

 

Hi!

We are Sigma Lambda Gamma National Sorority Inc.- Alpha Chapter and Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity Inc.- Alpha Chapter We are here to raise money for Pallium India.

Pallium India is a nonprofit organization aimed at helping men and women in India of all ages in their fight against terminal illness, disabilities, chronic diseases, etc.

This past winter, two of our members had the opportunity to travel abroad and work with Pallium India. These two members were amazed and touched by the incredible work that Pallium India does with their patients. Pallium India goes above and beyond what we, in the U.S., expect from palliative and hospice care. Pallium India has helped patients and their families build new homes, start small businesses, and even provide children with scholarships to put them through school and college.

Following is a letter that one of our members had written describing their experience working with Pallium India:

"India was an amazing and eye opening journey where I met so many loving, caring, and hard working people. There are no words to describe the experience I had in India...it's definitely a whole other world over there. My mom had told me that India can be the most beautiful place you've ever been as well as the ugliest. I saw both sides and she was right. The people, I would say, were the most beautiful part of India. I have never felt so welcomed and appreciated.
    The organization we were working with is called Pallium India. Pallium is a nationally registered charitable trust created to fight for the needs of people who need hospice and palliative care. The doctors, nurses, and social workers that work for Pallium are by far the most dedicated and passionate team of people I have ever met. These beautiful people have dedicated their lives to giving a voice to people who haven't been heard before. Pallium India goes above and beyond what palliative and hospice care does here in the U.S. An example being that when a man had tongue cancer (keep in mind it was so severe that he could no longer swallow) and all he had for a home were stones for tables and leaves for beds, Pallium India built them a home and even gave the family chickens so they could start their own small business.
    Pallium India and the people who work for the organization touched me in a way I didn't think possible. I knew the experience would be impacting, but I didn't realize just how much this organization would touch me.
    Thank you again for helping me! You all were very much a part of my experience there and have already helped Pallium India by sending me there to help them for the weeks I was there. I will continue to pursue my education and strive to do what Pallium India does everyday; fight for those who feel don't have a voice and help as many people as I can."

story:
Meu nome é Abidan Henrique da Silva e tenho 16 anos. Eu estudei toda a minha vida em escola pública, até que, em 2012, pelo projeto Bolsa Talento de uma ONG chamada ISMART, ganhei uma bolsa integral para estudar numa escola particular que tem por nome Sidarta. Lá, graças a Deus eu tenho tido bons resultados mantendo excelentes notas, sendo agraciado com um premio no Fórum FAAP, uma menção honrosa na OBF e ganhando a bolsa Robert Wong para estudar na Harvard Summer School agora de junho a agosto de 2014.

Essa bolsa para Harvard é importantíssima para mim, pois realizará meu sonho de estudar fora do país e também porque é a concretização de todo meu esforço e superação uma vez que eu havia tentado essa mesma bolsa no ano retrasado e tinha perdido pela defasagem no inglês, no entanto eu não desisti, estudei muito, e em novembro do ano passado ganhei.

Infelizmente a bolsa não cobre todos os meus custos, consequentemente, preciso arcar com despesas como a passagem, transporte, alimentação fora do campus, etc. E por isso surgiu a ideia da criação desse Campanha Colaborativa que possibilidade a você, veja só, a oportunidade de contribuição com a realização desse meu sonho.

Informações importantes:

- Todos os "presentinhos" começarão a ser entregues a partir de agosto;

- Para os tamanhos do agasalho e da camiseta, entraremos em contato pelo através do e-mail informado;

- As contribuições são em dólares americanos (USD)

Obrigado pela sua colaboração!

story:
Opportunity to Follow My Life Path

Greetings Friends, Family, Comrades and Loved Ones,

I need your support!  I have an opportunity to gain much needed skills and training while also pursuing my life's path as a healer/organizer.  This opportunity will allow me to work more effectively within community/ Nation.  In less than one week I begin an unpaid full-time (40-50hrs/week)  6-month Apprenticeship in Organic Farming and Gardening @ UC Santa Cruz.  I believe these skills will be of great benefit to myself and to our community as we struggle for self-determination and liberation.  Fellows from across the country and from all over the world have attended this program and used their skills and experiences, as well as food, as tools for economic justice work, land based struggle and local/ global sustainability projects.  Free The Land!!!

                           

Your support is everything to me.  By giving today, you will give me the ability to purchase necessary tools and equipment, cover my transportation/ travel costs, and provide me with a small monthly stipend.  

Your contributions will be directly supporting my educational advancement, practical/political development and spiritual/ transformation journey; allowing me to work within Community/ Nation with greater skill and efficiency. 

Thank You, Asante Sana for your spiritual and financial support and love.

Blessings.... 


Who is Kana Azhari?

           

I am...

Womyn, New Afrikan, Daughter, Sister, Aunt, Friend, Organizer, Healer, Educator, Spirit Seeker, Transformer, Artist, Writer, Creator, Counselor, Community Member, Dreamer, Lover, Care Giver, Wellness Practitioner, Vegan/ Vegan Caterer, Learner, Teacher, Coordinator, Chronic Thinker, Dancer, Fitness Instructor, Scout Leader, Self-Care Advocate, Risk-Taker, Tree Huger & Nature/ Element Lover, and Creative Soul.    

"Self-Determination is the Gospel"                -Kana Azhari


I Need Your Support...  

Over the next 6-months I will be learning/ working/ participating in an unpaid Full-Time Apprenticeship @ UC Santa Cruz.  I was awarded scholarships totaling $6000 which covers my tuition and fees.  I need your help covering some of the additional costs.  

  1. Supplies and Materials: books, herbs, seeds, tools, rubber boots and work boots, rain and weather gear, hats, hot/cold farm clothing, "tent cabin" furnishings, food storage and cooking wear, food, drinking water, etc.
  2. Travel/Transportation Costs For Community Work:  Over the next 6-months there are several meetings, trainings, community events, educational/ political conferences and engagements (in and outside of Santa Cruz) that I will need to attend.  Your contribution will cover my travel/ transportation expenses and allow me to continue doing my community work and enrich my study.
  3. Health Care: While I recognize the benefit/ Right for folks to have access to "health care", personally, I have chosen to relay primarily on healing herbs, a balanced diet, and healthy lifestyle.  However, I am required to have health insurance for this program.  I have looked into a few options that are still pending.  In the meantime I am in need of financial resources in order to purchase temporary insurance, ASAP.


Any and All Support is Welcomed...

Warm greetings and thanks to all who have been able to make the resources available to contribute.  From my heart I am grateful.  Forward thanks for all who will give.  

...And RGB love to all who are supporting me in spirit, in light, and through principled unity...pushing forward our collective vision and work.

                                                                

Thank You! 


We all have networks.  Please forward this link and share my story with others.  Who knows?... Maybe they can help... $1 Million or $10 Million, I mean... every little bit helps :)
story_txt:
Opportunity to Follow My Life PathGreetings Friends, Family, Comrades and Loved Ones,I need your support!  I have an opportunity to gain much needed skills and training while also pursuing my life's path as a healer/organizer.  This opportunity will allow me to work more effectively within community/ Nation.  In less than one week I begin an unpaid full-time (40-50hrs/week)  6-month Apprenticeship in Organic Farming and Gardening @ UC Santa Cruz.  I believe these skills will be of great benefit to myself and to our community as we struggle for self-determination and liberation.  Fellows from across the country and from all over the world have attended this program and used their skills and experiences, as well as food, as tools for economic justice work, land based struggle and local/ global sustainability projects.  Free The Land!!!                           Your support is everything to me.  By giving today, you will give me the ability to purchase necessary tools and equipment, cover my transportation/ travel costs, and provide me with a small monthly stipend.  Your contributions will be directly supporting my educational advancement, practical/political development and spiritual/ transformation journey; allowing me to work within Community/ Nation with greater skill and efficiency. Thank You, Asante Sana for your spiritual and financial support and love.Blessings.... Who is Kana Azhari?           I am...Womyn, New Afrikan, Daughter,
Sister, Aunt, Friend, Organizer, Healer, Educator, Spirit Seeker, Transformer,
Artist, Writer, Creator, Counselor, Community Member, Dreamer, Lover, Care
Giver, Wellness Practitioner, Vegan/ Vegan Caterer, Learner, Teacher, Coordinator, Chronic Thinker, Dancer, Fitness Instructor, Scout
Leader, Self-Care Advocate, Risk-Taker, Tree Huger & Nature/ Element Lover, and Creative Soul.    
"Self-Determination is the
Gospel"                -Kana

story:
Short Summary

Hello! I'm Paul Johnson and I am 17 years old.  

I'm honored to have been accepted to Berklee College of Music's Professional Program.  I am determined to use my musical talents to inspire others and spread joy in the world. I respect many musical giants and hope to follow in their footsteps.  I am truly humbled that many support my efforts to raise my tuition to attend Berklee College of Music! Some giants such as Robin Eubanks, Lonnie Plaxico, Tyrone Birkett, Duane Harden and Ryan Shaw!

  • I invite you to share my musical journey to Berklee College of Music and beyond. Your generous donation will enable me to further develop my musical and academic talents
  • Please join supporters from around the world in this shared journey!
  • Any amount is sincerely appreciated.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Berklee College of Music 4 year tuition is $240,000.00.  Thus far, I have been rewarded $21,000.00. Thus, I am doing all that I can to empower myself to raise the balance due.
  • THE REWARDS ARE AMAZING! Please scroll down to see the amazing rewards that you could receive. Awards such as Backstage Visits with Broadway and Jazz Legends; Private Quartet Performance;  Private songwriting lessons and more!!!
  • If I don't reach the entire goal, I  hope to raise enough for my freshman year....but I believe that, together with you...WE Can Do It!:-)

The Impact

Education is mandatory in my family! Ever since I was little, I wanted to go to college. Most importantly, because I am excited of merging my love of music with my love of academics.  "Books and Music" is my motto!

"I am delighted to support Paul Johnson as he takes another step in his musical journey. Having known his parents for years who are extraordinary musicians in their own right, Paul is displaying the potential of a creative musician that will be a force to be reckoned with in the future. Please support him as he endeavors to take his gift to the next level."

Tyrone Birkett Saxophonist, Composer, Producer


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support, you can help?

  • Would you please share with your family and friends on all of your social media platforms?
  • Oh! And please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks so much! 

Paul "Papa Bear" Johnson

story:
Hello, my name is Ricardo Guadalupe Robles. I am a senior who attends Marshall Fundamental Secondary School in Pasadena, California. This is my last year in the public school system, and I believe it is time for me to give back to the community I grew up in. Many children in my community, unfortunately, do not receive the school supplies they need and deserve. With my campaign, you and I  will be able to raise enough money to buy young scholars a backpack, notebook, pencils, and markers.

My goal is to raise $1000. What I’m asking is for people to make $5 donations.  That's it. I'm only asking for $5. Nothing more and nothing less. 

 You will help many students start the school year off with school supplies and a big smile. Growing up, I witnessed students ,who could not afford a backpack, use a cheap plastic shopping bag as a backpack.

One challenge I face is promoting my campaign. There is the chance that I will not be able to raise enough funds to help the children of my neighborhood. Another challenge will be my ability to deliver the supplies on time. Fortunately, Indiegogo will help with the promoting because you could easily share my campaign with the Indiegogo share tools. To make sure I am able to deliver the supplies on time, I have deadlines set up and I am also limiting this campaign to 3 weeks.


Together we make a difference.

story:
Krystal Skinner Memorial Scholarship Fund

Krystal Skinner, 22, of Lindenwold, NJ, was stabbed to death on March 26, 2008 in an apparent domestic violence dispute.  Krystal, who had a two year old son, was a senior at Rutgers University-Camden and a social work major interning with the Division of Youth and Family Services (DYFS), scheduled to graduate in two months.  She was enrolled in the Baccalaureate Child Welfare Education Stipend Program and looking forward to a job with DYFS upon her graduation.  Krystal was posthumously inducted into the Phi Alpha National Social Work Honor Society in April and awarded her BASW degree in May 2008. 

          The Krystal Skinner Memorial Scholarship Fund has been established to financially assist eligible individuals pursuing their social work degree at Rutgers University so that more students, like Krystal, will have the opportunity to realize their academic and professional goals of service and social justice. In memory of Krystal, the Rutgers community will come together on Saturday, March 24, 2012 for our 4th Annual Domestic Violence Walk to help raise awareness of this pervasive social issue and to raise the needed funds for the scholarship.

story:
Our Story

On July 18, 2011 my only child, Gabriella Jeanne, was tragically killed in an auto accident.  It was 3 weeks before her 17th birthday!


I wanted to honor her by creating this fund to support interests she was passionate about.   Marine biology and shark conservation were some of her interests.


Gabriella was in the process of applying to Texas A&M, majoring in Marine Biology.  That is why I had felt moved to start a memorial scholarship in her honor here.  Her life was cut short, and I know she would be proud knowing we are going to help others, in her honor, fulfill their dreams.


I have started an endowment with the Texas A&M Foundation.  This endowment will help allow students like Gabriella, who love and are passionate about the ocean and marine life, get the education necessary to work in the Marine Biology field.  The funds I will raise will go toward this commitment ($25,000). That amount is the contract amount I had pledged to raise.  However, personally, I have a goal of raising $100,000.


This endowment, THE GABRIELLA JEANNE MEMORIAL SCHOLARSHIP will remain at the university, for the life of the university.  Her spirit, her memory, her passion, and all that we put into this will never end.  We will be impacting so many lives, and quite honestly, all because of the LOVE I have for my daughter.  I want something GREAT to come from all this pain and loss.  We miss her so much, but I know her LOVE and PASSION remains!  Thatâ€™s awesome!


Here is what Texas A&M wrote after I started the scholarship:


Texas A&M University at Galveston establishes the Gabriella Jeanne Memorial Scholarship

     (Galveston, TX-Sept. 23, 2011) - - When an endowed scholarship program for $25,000 was established by Robert Roetman to honor the memory of his daughter, Gabriella Jeanne, some wondered why this New Jersey native would fund a Texas A&M University at Galveston scholarship. Others wanted to contribute to the scholarship to honor this generous donor whose only tie to the university was the love of his daughter.

     Gabriella loved marine mammals and conservation. It was her dream to pursue a career in marine biology and attend Texas A&M University at Galveston. But when she was involved in a fatal traffic accident, many thought her dream had ended. But, her father decided to keep her dream and memory alive by funding the education of those who have the same aspirations as his daughter.

     â€œGabriella loved the ocean,â€ Robert said. â€œI chose to endow a scholarship at Texas A&M University at Galveston, because it was my daughter's dream to attend college there. We both love the ocean and I always had a hope for the future for us. For me, I need to focus on something that will bring good out of this tragedy, and if I can help one if not many people go after their passion, go after their dream, that's what I'm aiming for.â€

Although Robert committed $25,000 for the endowment over five years, he says his personal goal is to raise $100,000.


Full Article:  http://www.tamug.edu/develop/Campaigns/GabriellaScholarship.html


The Impact

Helping others reach their goals and dreams through this scholarship.  That is what this is all about.  Keeping my daughter's spirit alive, and knowing that she will be smiling down on me.  This tragedy can have paralyzing days.  Knowing I am helping others in her honor keeps me moving forward.  This scholarship will help kids, like her, move forward.  I love that!


What We Need & What You Get

This website is only one way I am seeking to raise funds.  In October of this past year, I held my first EVER fundraiser in the town where I grew up, Midland Park, NJ.  Many individuals and businesses made this event, the HOMETOWN HALLOWEEN FUNDRAISER a success.  We raised over $2,000 that night.  Not bad for my first one, I thought.


All donations made to the GABRIELLA JEANNE MEMORIAL SCHOLARSHIP are TAX DEDUCTIBLE through the TEXAS A&M FOUNDATION.  That helps!

Other Ways You Can Help

Please tell everyone you know, and help us blow past our goal to help other kids.  Check out the website and LIKE us on FACEBOOK.  And most of all THANK YOU!


WWW.GABRIELLAJEANNEMEMORIALFUND.COM


https://www.facebook.com/InMemoryOfGabriellaJeanne

story:
Our Story

Axis has been equipping communities to move from apathy to compassionate action since 2006. Over the past 6  years, we have challenged over 40,000 people at over 200 venues to set aside their distractions and make a real difference in the world. We are launching an exciting new 1,000-Day Plan to reach more people and help them grow deeper in their faith. In a couple of weeks, we will be having a banquet to launch this new plan. This $2,000 will go directly toward paying for the banquet, and will allow for 100% of all money raised at the banquet to go directly to Axis. 

The Impact

By being a part of this banquet, you are helping us reach more people than ever before. Over this past year, we have seen: a mom reunited with her son; a junior-high class student government lead well by examining their own music choices and challenging the underclassmen to follow their example; and students come to know Jesus as their Savior. Your financial support allows us to not only continue our ministry, but also to expand and see more stories like this happen every day. 


What We Need & What You Get

By helping us cover the cost of the banquet, you are allowing us to offer the dinner free of charge to participants. Each participant will then have the opportunity to invest in Axis' new 1,000-Day Plan. This new strategy includes reaching out to parents more than we ever have before, while expanding our ministry directly to students. The big goals of our 1,000-Day Plan include creating effective follow-up tools for communities to grow deeper in their relationship with Christ, as well as ways for Axis to become financially sustainable as an organization. We believe God has given us a vision for making a difference in the world, and by donating now, you can join us in accomplishing this exciting mission.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell your friends and family about this IndieGoGo campaign using Facebook and Twitter.


All gifts made through PayPal are fully tax deductible!

story:
Our Story

My name is Anastasia Somoza and I am 28 years old and living in New York City.  Since graduating from Georgetown University with a BA in Government, I have been unable to find a job outside of unpaid internships.  An extraordinary opportunity is paving the way for me to enjoy a productive and exciting career. This past spring, I received a full scholarship to read for my master's degree in human rights at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE). 

 

This is the second round of funding for my campaign to fund 4 community service volunteers to help me complete a masters degree at the London School of Economics.   Thanks to the wonderful family, friends, and well wishers, we raised $21, 174 - not our $30,000 goal, but great all the same.  After deductions, $18,607 will go into my account towards payment for my aides.    

 

Here's a little background. Throughout my life, my mother has had to fight to get an education for me and for my twin sister Alba, who is also significantly disabled with cerebral palsy. The greatest battle was with the public schools, where we fought to attend regular classes rather than be relegated to special education classes, which at that time amounted to little more than warehousing for students with special needs.     

 

This is the status quo. In New York City, Medicaid pays for my aide full time, even if I sit home watching television all day.  Through a Medicaid waiver, I was able to provide funding for an aide to help me during my time at Georgetown University. However, the story changes when financing is needed to support an aide during study overseas.  Medicaid will no longer fund any student's aide outside of New York.

 

Since last year, my mother and I have worked on legislation that would allow students accepted by an institution of higher learning to take their aide with them while in school. Following my acceptance by LSE, we worked closely with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services on securing a waiver that would enable my aide to accompany me to London. But just two days before our flight to Heathrow, we received a call denying us that waiver.   

 

We went to London anyway, tried and failed to secure funding, and at the 11th hour a friend offered to fund an aide for two months while we tried to fundraise.   An aide came to help me, but it did not work out and she returned abruptly to the U.S.   I had no choice but to come back, seek a deferment of my scholarship, and continue with the fundraising so I may return in September 2012.

 

While I was devastated to have to leave LSE, something wonderful resulted from all the bad things that happened. An emeritus member of the Board of Governors became involved in helping me with the school administration to effect some important changes, which hopefully will be in place when I return in September 2012. One of the things that made my situation worse then it already was involved the accessibility of the LSE residence. It was impossible for me to get to my room independently. I had to go through three large fire doors that I could not open on my own. The door to my own room was not accessible. In actual fact, the entire room was not accessible.

 

The meeting was great!  The LSE agreed to make significant accessibility changes to their residences, fund a room for my aides, and work with SCOPE (England's equivalent to United Cerebral Palsy) to make the LSE fully accessible to the extent possible for all students with disabilities.

 

I am hoping that you will all help me to get the word out about our cause in any way you can. I will keep you all updated on how we are doing via the website. Thank you for believing in me, thank you for all your efforts in helping me to achieve my goal. I look at this bad episode as a lesson in life, to overcome adversity, and to never give up no matter what the odds.

 

Please understand that this is a situation where every little bit really will help! I shall be sincerely grateful for any financial assistance from friends, family, and members of the public. From my end, I pledge to be a dedicated and hardworking student, and, as a graduate, to go out into the world at large and help improve conditions for others like myself.

 

The Impact

It's my firm belief that the impact of our campaign will lead to an awareness of the obstacles that people with disabilities face when trying to access higher education. If any non-disabled student received the type of wonderful scholarship opportunity that I have, he/she would not have to decline the offer because of the need for a personal-care aide. My mother and I continue our work together on legislation that will enable students with any disability that necessitates personal-care assistance to take their aide with them if they are enrolled at an institution of higher education. Long-term, this legislation will help people with disabilities to reach their maximum potential and have a better shot at becoming employed. It will also get them off social services and help them to become independent and enjoy a better quality of life.

What We Need & What You Get

 We do need to continue raising funds to cover the approximate cost of funding 4 community volunteers to assist me.   The cost is $10,000 a year per volunteer.   British law only allows the volunteers to work a certain number of hours per week, so for the right coverage, we need to have 4 volunteers.   As it is so costly, we are probably going to have more the two campaigns in order to raise enough money.  At $40,000 a year, the total we need for the two years is $80,000.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations from friends, family, associates and the public at large will, of course, be the greatest help. Additionally, I ask each of you to become an ambassador for my campaign. Please spread the word among your own circle of friends and contacts through Facebook and other social-media channels. This will rapidly build awareness, and will truly help me reach my fundraising goal. And of course, outreach to local media contacts you may have can also help tremendously in getting the message out.  We are also looking into the possibility of a corporate sponsor funding one community service volunteer.  I feel it will not be so onerous to fund $10,000 for one volunteer as opposed to funding the whole amount.  So, if you have any contacts or know of corporations that provide grants to people with disabilities, please let us know.
story_txt:
Our Story
My name is Anastasia Somoza and I am 28 years old and living in New York City.  Since graduating from Georgetown University with a BA in Government, I have been unable to find a job outside of unpaid internships.  An extraordinary opportunity is paving the way for me to enjoy a productive and exciting career. This past spring, I received a full scholarship to read for my master's degree in human rights at the London School of Economics and Political Science (LSE). 
 
This is the second round of funding for my campaign to fund 4 community service volunteers to help me complete a masters degree at the London School of Economics.   Thanks to the wonderful family, friends, and well wishers, we raised $21, 174 - not our $30,000 goal, but great all the same.  After deductions, $18,607 will go into my account towards payment for my aides.    
 
Here's a little background. Throughout my life, my mother has had to fight to get an education for me and for my twin sister Alba, who is also significantly disabled with cerebral palsy. The greatest battle was with the public schools, where we fought to attend regular classes rather than be relegated to special education classes, which at that time amounted to little more than warehousing for students with special needs.     
 
This is the status quo. In New York City, Medicaid pays for my aide full time, even if I sit home watching television all day.  Through a Medicaid waiver, I was able to provide funding for an aide to help me during my time at Georgetown University. However, the story changes when financing is needed to support an aide during study overseas.  Medicaid will no longer fund any student's aide outside of New York.
 
Since last year, my mother and I have worked on legislation that would allow students accepted by an institution of higher learning to take their aide with them while in school. Following my acceptance by LSE, we worked closely with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services on securing a waiver that would enable my aide to accompany me to London. But just two days before our flight to Heathrow, we received a call denying us that waiver.   
 
We went to London anyway, tried and failed to secure funding, and at the 11th hour a friend offered to fund an aide for two months while we tried to fundraise.   An aide came to help me, but it did not work out and she returned abruptly to the U.S.   I had no choice but to come back, seek a deferment of my scholarship, and continue with the fundraising so I may return in September 2012.
 
While I was devastated to have to leave LSE, something wonderful resulted from all the bad things that happened. An emeritus member of the Board of Governors became involved in helping me with the school administration to effect some important changes, which hopefully will be in place when I return in September 2012. One of the things that made my situation worse then it already was involved the accessibility of the LSE residence. It was impossible for me to get to my room independently. I had to go through three large fire doors that I could not open on my own. The door to my own room was not accessible. In actual fact, the entire room was not accessible.
 
The meeting was great!  The LSE agreed to make significant accessibility changes to their residences, fund a room for my aides, and work with SCOPE (England's equivalent to United Cerebral Palsy) to make the LSE fully accessible to the extent possible for all students with disabilities.
 
I am hoping that you will all help me to get the word out about our cause in any way you can. I will keep you all updated on how we are doing via the website. Thank you for believing in me, thank you for all your efforts in helping me to achieve my goal. I look at this bad episode as a lesson in life, to overcome adversity, and to never give up no matter what the odds.
 
Please understand that this is a situation where every little bit really will help! I shall be sincerely grateful for any financial assistance from friends, family, and members of the public. From my end, I pledge to be a dedicated and hardworking student, and, as a graduate, to go out into the world at large and help improve conditions for others like myself.
 
The Impact
It's my firm belief that the impact of our campaign will lead to an awareness of the obstacles that people with disabilities face when trying to access higher education. If any non-disabled student received the type of wonderful scholarship opportunity that I have, he/she would not have to decline the offer because of the need for a personal-care aide. My mother and I continue our work together on legislation that will enable students with any disability that necessitates personal-care assistance to take their aide with them if they are enrolled at an institution of higher education. Long-term, this legislation will help people with disabilities to reach their maximum potential and have a better shot at becoming employed. It will also get them off social services and help them to become independent and enjoy a better quality of life.
What We Need & What You Get
 We do need to continue raising funds to cover the approximate cost of funding 4 community volunteers to assist me.   The cost is $10,000 a year per volunteer.   British law only allows the volunteers to work a certain number of hours per week, so for the right coverage, we need to have 4 volunteers.   As it is so costly, we are probably going to have more the two campaigns in order to raise enough money.  At $40,000 a year, the total we need for the two years is $80,000.   
 
Other Ways You Can Help
Donations from friends, family, associates and the public at large will, of course, be the greatest help. Additionally, I ask each of you to become an ambassador for my campaign. Please spread the word among your own circle of friends and contacts through Facebook and other social-media channels. This will rapidly build awareness, and will truly help me reach my fundraising goal. And of course, outreach to local media contacts you may have can also help tremendously in getting the message out.  We are also looking into the possibility of a corporate sponsor funding one community service volunteer.  I feel it will not be so onerous to fund $10,000 for one volunteer as opposed to funding the whole amount.  So, if you have any contacts or know of corporations that provide grants to people with disabilities, please let us know.

story:
WHO 

Be More Heroic is an non-profit anti-bullying campaign dedicated to inspiring individuals and communities to stimulate positive, proactive and courageous action in their daily lives.

We invite individuals to redefine heroism by sharing actions that show great determination in advocating against bullying and social change. 

Our Mission: To create a world free of complacency in which everyone chooses to be a hero.  

Our Vision: Through our projects and services we will inspire individuals to become influential, compassionate and engaged advocates against bullying who seek to make an impact in their surrounding schools and communities. 

EMPOWERMENT

A place to empower ourselves and one another...

RESPONSIBILITY 

A place to take responsibility for ourselves and one another...

COMPASSION & SERVICE

A place where compassion and service to others is performed effortlessly...


The Be More Heroic team strongly feels that bullying has become a dangerous crisis world-wide. It is a part of our mission to do all we can to not only help raise awareness but resolve the issue to the best of our ability.

In order to kick-start our anti-bullying campaign, in November 2011, we recorded a cover and music video of Foster the People's, Pumped Up Kicks. Reaching over 50,000 views and garnering incredible feedback.

Shortly after releasing the video we launched our site http://bemoreheroic.com. Here we asked our followers to inspire us and others by creating video responses to the question,'What could I do to help end bullying?' You can find some of the awesome responses from followers all over the world also on our site as well as on our YouTube Channel www.youtube.com/bemoreheroic. 

The digital response we received instantaneously prompted us to act beyond a digital campaign, we wanted to bring our message directly to every school across the nation and eventually internationally.

WHAT

That said, Be More Heroic launched the Be More Heroic Fall 2012 School Tour featuring nationally acclaimed Singer/Songwriter Dani Shay, Singer/Songwriter Justin Chase, Actress/Comedian Darmirra Brunson and Student Advocate Savanna Raven.

Be More Heroic has curated an assembly style program, for junior high and high schools levels, to educate the youth on the issue of bullying through music and expert-inspired activities.

The purpose of the B.M.H. School Tour program is to educate the youth on the issue of bullying through music, comedy and student and expert inspired activities. This highly interactive program speaks with the students and administration not to them. 

While the foundation of the program will maintain the same message throughout each school, we will work with the students, faculty and surrounding community to evolve the program specific to your school’s needs in order to leave students with tangible resources to utilize far beyond presentation day.

The most important resource we will leave each school with is the implementation of the Be More Heroic club. We will work with the administrators prior to the assembly to choose 4-7 reliable, passionate students to take on a position and one administrator to advise and maintain the campus club.

We will provide a starter kit to each club with all of the necessary resources to assist them in preserving the club for years to come. 

In doing this we hope to create student advocates against bullying and community leaders who inspire and stimulate proactive and courageous action within themselves, their fellow students and surrounding community. 

WHY

In order to provide each school with the necessary amount of resources needed to not only execute the program on assembly day but to continue building the program far beyond presentation day for the students, administrators and parents we need the proper funding. 

These resources include:

  • T-shirts
  • Wrist bands
  • Banners (Every student will sign on assembly day as their pledge against bullying and the school will find a place to permanently hang it up to act as a reminder everyday)
  • Reading materials for the kids, parents and administrators (Brochures, outreach programs, recommended readings, counseling services, other anti-bullying non profit organization materials...etc.)
  • Classroom activities for the administrators
  • Cardboard, paper, paint, pens etc. for the hype week leading up to assembly day 

...and the list goes on!

In order to provide each Be More Heroic club with the proper resources to not only kick-start the club but to maintain a prominent anti-bullying advocate club within each school, again, we need the proper funding. 

These resources include:

  • $50-$100 stipend
  • Printed and bound handbooks with bylaws, officer roles and so forth..
  • Pens, paper and other standard office supplies
  • Promotional Be More Heroic material 
HOW
  • Donate!

Every single dollar counts, help us make a difference and bring this bullying epidemic to an end one school at a time.

  • Share the PSA!

The more people we can get the word out to the better our chances are at reaching our goal in 60 days.

  • Go to http://bemoreheroic.com and post a video response to What Can I Do to End Bullying?

We would LOVE to hear what you can do to end bullying, it might just inspire us to add something to our assembly curriculum!

  • Like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/BeMoreHeroic & Follow us on Twitter @Be_More_Heroic

Leave us articles, poems, videos or quotes that inspire you. Ask us questions, get to know us!

We would LOVE to hear what you can do to end bullying, it might just inspire us to add something to our assembly curriculum!

Like us on Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/BeMoreHeroic & Follow us on Twitter @Be_More_Heroic

story:
Message from David Bunnell, founder of Macworld and PC World magazines, friend of Andrew Fluegelman: 

The late Andrew Fleugelman and I worked closely with Steve Jobs on the creation of Macworld magazine back in 1983, before the Macintosh was introduced to the world during the 1984 Super Bowl. 

Andrew was a brilliant writer, editor and programmer. He wrote the first communication program for PC's called "PC-Talk." In order to get his program into the market, he gave it away for free and asked people to make donations. This method of software distribution became known as "shareware."

Andrew died tragically in 1986 and we created a fund to honor him. This fund is still alive today and each year we give away new Macintosh Laptop computers to 5 deserving  college-bound students who grew up in poverty and otherwise challenging circumstances.

We also provide a printer to each student, software, and training. 

2011 Andrew Fluegelman Fellowship Award winners. Pictured left to right: Teyani Odom, Selma Verdin, Ezekiel Perez, Marissa Yarbrough, and LaShae Robinson.

The results so far have been amazing. All of our students are doing very well in college and the computers have made a huge difference. You can read about this success on our Facebook page --http://facebook.com/AndrewFleugelman

Why we are asking for help 

We need your help if this program is to continue into the future and grow.  

At this point, we only have the funds to give away five computers this year and five next year. We'd like to give away 20 or more per year and we'd like to think our program will become sustainable.

Andrew believed that the personal computer has the power to positively change anyone's life for the better.

The Andrew Fleuegelman Fellowships prove this is true.

How YOU can Help

You can make a tax deductable donation from $25 to $2500 below (see perks) or you can help spread the word by liking the Andrew Fluegelman Foundation Facebook Page (see link above) and by recommending us to your friends.

story:
In 2008 the Glass Student House was organized for the first time. Due to its success it was organized it again in 2009. 2010 was the year of making changes: the house was replaced by a bus. Now, in 2013, we take this project to a whole new level. With a bus and a mobile studio on five different locations, a team of students will produce 121 hours of live non-stop radio for this project. The following five locations are the locations we are going to visit: The Hague, Delft, Rotterdam, Amsterdam and Haarlem. However, in order to do this, we need support.

Unfortunately, organizing the Glass Student Bus is not cheap. With the use of crowd funding we try to cover as much of the costs as we can. Our goal is at this page, but we want to raise as much money as we can because the more money we raise, the more we can donate to the Red Cross!

Large donations will receive a special place on our Social Media pages; imagine your name on our Twitter page, Facebook page and website. When you donate €1.000, €2.500 or €5.000, we will offer you one of our sponsor packages. With every donation, you may request a song which we will play, guaranteed!

Do you want to participate in this project and create brand awareness at unique target group? Do not hesitate, donate and share our action! 

In 2008 werd voor het eerst het Glazen Studentenhuis georganiseerd. Door het succes daarvan werd dit in 2009 ook gedaan. In 2010 werd het roer omgegooid en veranderde het huis in een bus. Nu, in 2013, pakken we het grootser aan dan ooit. Met een bus en een mobiele studio op vijf verschillende locaties, zal een team van studenten 121 uur live non-stop radio maken voor deze actie. De vijf locaties die wij bezoeken zijn Den Haag, Delft, Rotterdam, Amsterdam en Haarlem. Maar daar hebben wij steun bij nodig.

Helaas is het organiseren van de Glazen Studentenbus niet goedkoop. Door middel van crowdfunding proberen wij zo veel mogelijk van deze kosten te dekken. Ons doel staat hier op de pagina, maar in principe willen wij zoveel mogelijk geld ophalen. Maar, hoe meer er gedoneerd wordt, hoe meer wij kunnen betekenen voor het Rode Kruis!

Grote donaties noemen wij uiteraard op onze sociale media, denk hierbij aan Twitter, Facebook en onze website. Bij donaties van €1.000, €2.500 en €5.000 worden er sponsorpakketten aangeboden. Bij iedere donatie mag er een aanvraag gedaan worden voor een liedje, deze wordt gegarandeerd gedraaid.

Wilt u meehelpen aan dit project en een stukje naamsbekendheid genereren? Aarzel dan niet, doneer en deel onze actie!

 

                           

When you donate €1.000, €2.500 or €5.000, we will offer you one of our sponsor packages. We will discuss this with you, in terms of what kind of advertisements you want. Do you want to participate in this project and create brand awareness at unique target group? Do not hesitate, donate and share our action!

When you make a donation for the Glass Student Bus, you are not only helping us, you are helping children in third world countries. These children have to deal with poor hygiene and are very vulnerable for potentially deadly diseases, like diarrhea. With your donation, you can help stop this.

We understand that you cannot always make a donation. In that case, we would really appreciate it if you follow us on Twitter and like our Facebook page. Please re-tweet and share our messages! If you do this, you show to your friends and followers that you support our action and you are asking them to do the same.

                                

Bij donaties van €1.000, €2.500 en €5.000 worden er sponsorpakketten aangeboden. Dit zullen wij dan uitgebreid bespreken met u. Wilt u meehelpen aan dit project en een stukje naamsbekendheid genereren? Aarzel dan niet, doneer en deel onze actie!

Als u doneert aan de Glazen Studentenbus, helpt u niet alleen ons, maar u helpt ook mee aan de vermindering van kindersterfte door diarree. Dit zijn vooral kinderen in derde wereldlanden. Deze kinderen hebben te maken met slechte hygiëne, waardoor zij sneller ziektes oplopen die hen het leven kosten. Met uw donatie maakt u hier dus een einde aan.

Nu kan het altijd voor komen dat u niet kan doneren. In dat geval helpt u ons al door ons te liken op Facebook en ons te volgen op Twitter. Deel en retweet vooral onze berichten! Hiermee laat u zien dat u ons steunt en roept u uw vrienden en volgers op om ons ook te steunen.


                                   

The Glass Student Buss is an important event for the Red Cross. Last year we collected 12 505€ with 100 hours of radio. In 2011 we collected 6 959€. We would really like to continue this upwards line and this year collect even more money. Every year a cheque is given to the Glass House of 3FM. They also call us "The pre-program for the Glass House", because we are busy from December 8th till December 13th. They begin on December 18th. The big difference between the Glass House and the Glass Student Buss is that the Glass Student Buss is organized by students. We get the change to create unique experiences with the support of companies and donors.

De Glazen Studentenbus is een belangrijk evenement voor het Rode Kruis. Vorig jaar hebben we met 100 uur radio €12.505 opgehaald. In 2011 haalden wij €6.959 op. Wij willen heel graag deze stijgende lijn voortzetten en dit jaar nog meer geld binnen te halen. Ieder jaar wordt er een cheque naar het Glazen Huis van 3FM gebracht. Zij noemen ons ook “het voorprogramma van het Glazen Huis”, omdat wij vanaf 8 december bezig zijn tot en met 13 december. Zij beginnen op 18 december. Het grote verschil tussen het Glazen Huis en de Glazen Studentenbus is dat de Glazen Studentenbus georganiseerd wordt door studenten. Wij krijgen de kans om unieke ervaringen op te doen, met steun van bedrijven en donateurs.


                               

We understand that you cannot always make a donation. In that case, we would really appreciate it if you follow us on Twitter and like our Facebook page. You could also add our special “Glazen Studentenbus” Twibbon to your Twitter profile picture. Please re-tweet and share our messages! If you do this, you show to your friends and followers that you support our action and you are asking them to do the same. With your support through Social Media, we can reach a whole lot more people and achieve much, much more.


Nu kan het altijd voor komen dat u niet kan doneren. In dat geval helpt u ons al door ons te liken op Facebook en ons te volgen op Twitter. Deel en retweet vooral onze berichten! Hiermee laat u zien dat u ons steunt en roept u uw vrienden en volgers op om ons ook te steunen.

* When requesting a song please send us your receipt of donation to glazenstudenten@gmail.com

friends and followers that you support our action and you are asking them to do
the same.

                                


Bij donaties van €1.000, €2.500 en €5.000 worden er sponsorpakketten
aangeboden. Dit zullen wij dan uitgebreid bespreken met u. Wilt u meehelpen aan
dit project en een stukje naamsbekendheid genereren? Aarzel dan niet, doneer en
deel onze actie!
Als u doneert
aan de Glazen Studentenbus, helpt u niet alleen ons, maar u helpt ook mee aan
de vermindering van kindersterfte door diarree. Dit zijn vooral kinderen in
derde wereldlanden. Deze kinderen hebben te maken met slechte hygiëne, waardoor
zij sneller ziektes oplopen die hen het leven kosten. Met uw donatie maakt u
hier dus een einde aan.
Nu kan het
altijd voor komen dat u niet kan doneren. In dat geval helpt u ons al door ons
te liken op Facebook en ons te volgen op Twitter. Deel en retweet vooral onze berichten!
Hiermee laat u zien dat u ons steunt en roept u uw vrienden en volgers op om
ons ook te steunen.



                                   


The Glass Student Buss is an important event for the Red Cross. Last year we collected 12 505€ with 100 hours of radio. In 2011 we collected 6 959€. We would really like to continue this upwards line and this year collect even more money. Every year a cheque is given to the Glass House of 3FM. They also call us "The pre-program for the Glass House", because we are busy from December 8th till December 13th. They begin on December 18th. The big difference between the Glass House and the Glass Student Buss is that the Glass Student Buss is organized by students. We get the change to create unique experiences with the support of companies and donors.


De Glazen
Studentenbus is een belangrijk evenement voor het Rode Kruis. Vorig jaar hebben
we met 100 uur radio €12.505 opgehaald. In 2011 haalden wij €6.959 op. Wij
willen heel graag deze stijgende lijn voortzetten en dit jaar nog meer geld
binnen te halen. Ieder jaar wordt er een cheque naar het Glazen Huis van 3FM
gebracht. Zij noemen ons ook “het voorprogramma van het Glazen Huis”, omdat wij
vanaf 8 december bezig zijn tot en met 13 december. Zij beginnen op 18
december. Het grote verschil tussen het Glazen Huis en de Glazen Studentenbus
is dat de Glazen Studentenbus georganiseerd wordt door studenten. Wij krijgen
de kans om unieke ervaringen op te doen, met steun van bedrijven en donateurs.




                               
We understand that you cannot always make a donation. In that case, we would really appreciate it if you follow us on Twitter and like our Facebook page. You could also add our special “Glazen Studentenbus” Twibbon to your Twitter profile picture. Please re-tweet and share our messages! If you do this, you show to your friends and followers that you support our action and you are asking them to do the same. With your support through Social Media, we can reach a whole lot more people and achieve much, much more.






Nu kan het altijd
voor komen dat u niet kan doneren. In dat geval helpt u ons al door ons te
liken op Facebook en ons te volgen op Twitter. Deel en retweet vooral onze
berichten! Hiermee laat u zien dat u ons steunt en roept u uw vrienden en
volgers op om ons ook te steunen.

* When requesting a song please send us your receipt of donation to glazenstudenten@gmail.com

story: Thank you for your support!
story_txt: Thank you for your support!

story:
Hispanic Student Recognition Program 

The Hispanic Student Recognition Program (HSRP), now in its 35th year, acknowledges exceptional achievements of middle and high school students throughout the state of Delaware.

This program provides recognition and scholarships to deserving Hispanic students who wish to further educate themselves. Additionally, the program inspires pride in the Latino Community, and encourages families and communities to support students who are in pursuit of greater opportunities.

High school students from each of Delaware's three counties receive awards in these categories:

·         Academics
·         Athletics
·         School/Community Service
·         Science Technology Engineering and Math (STEM) 
·         The Arts

Additionally, two high school students in the state will receive the Outstanding Hispanic High School Student of the Year award. Two middle school students will win the Outstanding Hispanic Middle School Student of the Year award.

Why donate to the HSRP?

There is a "Latino Education Crisis" occurring in Delaware and throughout the United States. In Delaware, only 66% of Latinos who enter 9th grade graduate from high school on time. Only 21% move on to college immediately after graduating, and only 14% move on to a second year of college (Harvard University, 2013). Similar trends happen around the United States; only 12% of Latinos in their mid to late 20s around the U.S. have a bachelor’s degree or higher (ASCD, 2010). 

The Latin American Community Center (LACC) seeks to reward students who have overcome a variety of barriers and to inspire other students to work hard to achieve their goals. 

2014 marks the 45th anniversary of the LACC, the 35th annual HSRP, and President & CEO Maria Matos' 20th year of service and leadership to our organization. Your donation to our 2014 Hispanic Student Recognition Program will allow us to provide scholarships and awards to students throughout the state of Delaware and will help the LACC continue our commitment to education.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this indiegogo campaign with all of your contacts.


For more information about how you can help with the Hispanic Student Recognition Program contact Sarah Hutton: shutton@thelatincenter.org or 302-655-7338 ex. 7699. To learn more about the Latin American Community Center and other ways to get involved, visit our website at www.thelatincenter.org


The LACC was founded in 1969 by Hispanic immigrants and community leaders who sought to establish a resource center for immigrants – a place to learn a new language and the ways of a new culture.  Forty-five years later, the LACC is a private, nonprofit organization serving 13,000 individuals annually.  Its mission is to advocate for and assist the Latino and wider community by offering services in a continuum of care that promotes empowerment and an enhanced quality of life while celebrating our diverse cultures.  Based in Wilmington’s Hilltop neighborhood, the LACC’s 100 bilingual, bicultural employees provide a wide range of services throughout New Castle County, including its satellite programs in Newport and Newark.

story:
From Washington D.C. to Tokai, Japan!

Hi, My name is Daishyana, or "Day" for short.  In a few short weeks I will be leaving my life and everything that I know, and moving on to the next dramatic chapter of my life! I will be teaching English to school children in a Japanese elementary school!  As excited as I am, I still need a lot of help transitioning from my life here in the states, to my new life in Tokai, Japan.  I am doing all that I can at my job now, but unfortunately it still isn't enough to get me started.  My parents aren't able to come up with the sufficient amount of funds, and I'm slowly running out of options.  Without the right amount of money my Japan move may come up short.

T h e  D r e a m

Since I was three years old, it has been my dream to travel, and possibly live in Japan.  I completely fell in love with the culture and the language, and tried making it a part of my daily life.  I've been studying Japanese on my own since I was twelve years old, and my goal is to become completely fluent within a year's time.  Amidst all my travels including Barcelona, Spain and Liverpool, England, Japan still drew me closer, and slowly kept calling my name.  Nothing makes me more ecstatic knowing that I'll be accomplishing one of my biggest dreams!  Living in Japan is everything to me, and I know this dream wouldn't be possible without the love and support of my parents, and most importantly God. :)



A Little Background

In 2012 I graduated with a Bachelors in Fine Arts (BFA) having majored in Vocal Performance and Jazz Studies.  Singing and music are huge parts of my life, and I use music in my teaching styles as well. I had the fortunate opportunity of teaching music and voice with a non-profit organization called Team of Stars.  It is a music camp dedicated to teaching inner city or "At-risk" children within the community learn the in's and out's of music production, and performing on stage. Kids with limited resources within their school and community were able to access music education where it normally wasn't present. Teaching in this program allowed me to get my feet in the water with hands-on teaching with kids.  The kids I taught were between the ages of 9-15.  After having that experience it made realize how much I love and enjoy teaching.  It made me not only want to teach others in my community, but around the world!


My Program

The company I will be working for is Interac.  It is a well-known program that allows candidates from all over the globe teach and become cultural ambassadors to children all over Japan from Northern Hokkaido to Southern Kyushu.  I was pushed by many of my friends and family to go for this dream full throttle, and apply.  Now, after applying I received the job as an Assistant Language Teacher, or "ALT", and will be living and working in Tokai in Ibaraki Prefecture.

Interac is an amazing program because they help you transition to your new life every step of the way.  They help train you for your new position, housing is found for us (even though we pay rent), and our jobs are placed and waiting for us.  There is a great support system within the employee network, and help is provided even whilst living in Japan.  They make sure you are never alone. :)


What I Need & Your Perks Too!

With my company it is highly recommended that I have a significant amount of money to help my transition to Japan become a smooth one.  The amount I am asking for is the amount they have suggested to me, which is about a month's salary before a receive my first paycheck.  That will be about two months after I arrive in Japan.  I will be responsible for my own rent, food, utilities, travel expenses, etc.

In return for your contributions, you will be receiving anything from a thank you card or postcard to a personalized gift package from me with amazing "omiyage" or goodies from Japan! Sounds awesome right?!

Any amount helps! Whether it's a dollar or 100 dollars, I am grateful for whatever you are willing to give. Again, any amount helps!

What Your Dollars Do:

This journey I am taking is something very genuine, and important to me for many reasons.  I want to start my new life doing something that I am passionate about and love dearly.  I hope that when you donate you know that you are investing in an amazing dream.  Your contributions become a part of my dream, and you make it known that no matter what ALL dreams are indeed possible.

-"Do what you love, and you will never work a day in your life."

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate anything at all, it's quite alright! Just spread the word! Be sure to post on Facebook, Twitter, etc. and tell your friends!

Arigatou Gozaimasu (Thank you) !
