story:
IT ALL STARTED in the Fall of 2012  I've had the opportunity to see very beautiful places in my life which has inspired me to give back to others. My faith is very important to me and I want to give back to children around the world. That's when I had the idea to bring faith back to children and families and educate children around the world about prayer! 

Short Summary

My name is Tina Whittaker. I am founder of Miracle Prayer Mat. Thank you for visiting! This is very important to me as my life purpose is to teach children how to become more comfortable, self confident & spiritually aware, so that they can put their best work into the world. 

The Miracle Prayer Mat is a tool for kids and families to use for daily prayer. 

 The  Miracle Prayer Mat is made out of soft yet durable,  non-flammable material what's unique about the mat is each mat has a religious images of different biblical characters and stories like Noah’s Ark (in the shape of the ark!) and David and Goliath



The Miracle Mat comes with a Miracle Prayers book for kids to create a better understanding of the importance of prayer. There will be an option to use an online application so that families can track prayer throughout the year as well. The purpose is to bring families together in prayer and help children understand the importance of prayer.   When you pray you are praying literally on biblical principles! The Miracle Prayer Mat can be easily folded, washed and stored after prayer. Each mat is large enough for children and adults!   

Miracle Prayer Mat, LLC produces a ready-to-use Prayer Mat and a book helping underprivileged children learn of the importance of prayer each day.


Miracle Prayer Mat teaches the foundation of prayer needed for proper spiritual growth during crucial development years. 

This means that children can do better than merely survive. With a spiritual relationship with God they can thrive. 

There's more good news: you can help!

so...

 We’ve already produced our first prototype. We’ve got a few retailers lined up and they feel the same way we do. 

So here's how it all breaks down:  

  • You want a Miracle Prayer Mat and book for yourself, family or friends
  • You buy a Miracle Prayer Mat and book
  • Because of your purchase, we send a Miracle Prayer Mat and book to a child who needs it

Miracle Prayer Mat- BUY ONE, GIVE ONE!

MONEY

WHY DO WE NEED YOUR MONEY? 

Because we are making a custom made Miracle Prayer Mat in the USA takes some serious factory action!!

The initial production run includes: 

 - Packaging

 - Design (w/customized our design)

 - Shipping (to get Miracle Prayer Mat from the factory to retailer shelves)

 - Stocking (because each retailer has a shelf fee)

When you add all these factors together - compounded with the miscellaneous costs and the fact that we need to produce Miracle Prayer Mats on our initial run to carry us for the next 6 months (Estimated break even point)...it comes out to roughly $65K.  

I know that sounds like a lot and that's because it is. All things considered, it's a lot because out of it, we get a lot.  

Think of it like someone who's producing a new album.  Though they have the heart and determination to make it happen, they need a whole lot more than a guitar and some fans.  They pay for recording, mixing, art work, producing and even a label fee!  Think of Miracle Prayer Mat like that...but rather than getting great tunes for your ears, you add increased favor from prayer to your life!

A FINAL NOTE

HELP to Give the Gift of Prayer!  BUY ONE, GIVE ONE  TO A CHILD IN NEED

•  Follow us on Facebook, Instagram, Twitter or Pinterest  post once a day for 30 days.

And that’s all there is to it!

story:
Our project battles the digital divide by organizing a digital scavenger hunt in downtown St. Paul for college bound teens and continuing education students. The hunt will teach and test them on vital technology skills necessary for life beyond high school.

Our idea is that we will have five teams of five college-bound participants, equipped with a smart phone for their group.  We will start
at the Science Museum of Minnesota and each team will travel to nine different nonprofits in the area by foot. We hope that each participant will not only learn and test necessary tech skills for college, but also learn about important resources in their community.

We have already secured five laptops that we will give away to the first place team and hope that we can obtain a second place prize with your help!

Participating Sites

The Saint Paul Chamber Orchestra
Saint Paul Neighborhood Network
Science Museum of Minnesota
The College of St. Scholastica
St. Paul Public Central Library
The Mayor's Office
Ordway Theater
Union Depot
YMCA

What does the money go toward?

The money will be used to purchase five Motorola Moto G phones.  These smartphones will serve two purposes - to be used by all teams during the scavenger hunt, and as the prize for the second place team.  Any extra funds we receive will go towards purchasing bus fair for the participants, team t-shirts, and small bonus rewards.

We have secured five laptops from Minnesota Computers for Schools, but we still need a smartphone or tablet addition to complete the functionality of the scavenger hunt.

Board Members

Eliza Summerlin
Chelsea Parker
Marie Tolan

Risks and Challenges

One risk is the time crunch. Our project will take place on June 10th, and we need the equipment before that time in order to run the scavenger hunt successfully.

We also fear that equipment may get damaged in the process of the hunt. We have liability releases to ensure that participants will be responsible for the technology that they use.

story:
Mission Statement

If you ask us when we started parkour, we might respond with, "When did you stop?" parkour was in every single one of us as a kid; jumping off swings, climbing trees, and hopping over cracks in the sidewalk. We encourage people to rediscover the creative, natural movement that we all loved when we were little kids. Training with us is fun and feels more like playing than exercising. We teach people to move their bodies in challenging new ways, while simultaneously improving the strength and mobility they need to live a long, healthy life.

Our goal is to create an environment in which people from movement arts such as parkour, freerunning, gymnastics, breakdancing, tricking, martial arts, aerial dance, and rock climbing can come together to learn, train, and collaborate. Our classes and open gyms are filled with like-minded people who genuinely want to see each other succeed. No matter how great you are at training alone, you will be further pushed and fueled by the camaraderie of our great community.

About APEX Movement Denver

APEX Movement began teaching in 2006 and after teaching out of other gyms for a few years, APEX Movement Denver opened in 2009. As the first gym to call our own, APEX Movement Denver has always been our low budget guinea pig to see if a parkour gym could be a viable small business. From our humble beginnings in a beat up warehouse in downtown Denver to our current facility in Englewood, we have grown steadily over the years with passion and integrity. APEX Movement Denver has educated and entertained hundreds of thousands of people through classes, performances, online videos, and more.

Our Plan

We have been searching for a new location and planning our move for almost 1 year. With sufficient savings already in the bank, a signed lease, and a proven business model 8 years in the running, this new gym is sure to succeed. We have enough money to run a successful gym with the current equipment, instructors, and classes we have. However, we have high expectations for the new space and we want to provide our members with the best possible equipment to learn, play, and grow on.

Why You Should Donate

APEX Movement is a world leader in the development of safe parkour instruction. We have spent almost 8 years refining our curriculum and teaching methods for parkour. To date, the growth of APEX Movement has relied solely on bootstrapping, without any debt or outside investment. Simply put, APEX Movement has always been a labor of love and passion. It has been founded, built, and sustained by freerunners, for freerunners. With your help, we will open up a world class facility to continue to be at the international forefront of parkour and freerunning.

Additionally, by contributing you will earn some awesome perks for helping our cause. See the sidebar on the right of this page for details.

What We Will Use the Money For

  • Lumber, metal, and labor costs

  • Foam to fill our massive, new foam pit

  • Contractors for an extensive buildout (plumbing, electric, etc.)

  • Real world obstacles such as I-beams, logs, and ladders

  • And many more epic surprises!

Other Ways to Help

If you can’t contribute money, you can still help by sharing this web link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media.

Copy, paste, and share this link: http://igg.me/at/apex/x/764370

Questions?

Feel free to send an email to denver@apexmovement.com!

Thank You for the Support

We are grateful for everyone who has supported us over the years. We love our jobs but we wouldn’t be able to do it without all our fantastic members, parents, and staff. It is an honor teaching and moving with every one of you. Prepare yourself for the best parkour gym ever!

Your friends in movement,

Ryan Ford, Cosmo Dudley, Vinny Fiacco, & the APEX Movement Denver staff
story_txt:
Mission StatementIf you ask us when we started parkour, we might respond with, "When did you stop?" parkour was in every single one of us as a kid; jumping off swings, climbing trees, and hopping over cracks in the sidewalk. We encourage people to rediscover the creative, natural movement that we all loved when we were little kids. Training with us is fun and feels more like playing than exercising. We teach people to move their bodies in challenging new ways, while simultaneously improving the strength and mobility they need to live a long, healthy life.Our goal is to create an environment in which people from movement arts such as parkour, freerunning, gymnastics, breakdancing, tricking, martial arts, aerial dance, and rock climbing can come together to learn, train, and collaborate. Our classes and open gyms are filled with like-minded people who genuinely want to see each other succeed. No matter how great you are at training alone, you will be further pushed and fueled by the camaraderie of our great community.About APEX Movement DenverAPEX Movement began teaching in 2006 and after teaching out of other gyms for a few years, APEX Movement Denver opened in 2009. As the first gym to call our own, APEX Movement Denver has always been our low budget guinea pig to see if a parkour gym could be a viable small business. From our humble beginnings in a beat up warehouse in downtown Denver to our current facility in Englewood, we have grown steadily over the years with passion and integrity. APEX Movement Denver has educated and entertained hundreds of thousands of people through classes, performances, online videos, and more.Our PlanWe have been searching for a new location and planning our move for almost 1 year. With sufficient savings already in the bank, a signed lease, and a proven business model 8 years in the running, this new gym is sure to succeed. We have enough money to run a successful gym with the current equipment, instructors, and classes we have. However, we have high expectations for the new space and we want to provide our members with the best possible equipment to learn, play, and grow on.Why You Should DonateAPEX Movement is a world leader in the development of safe parkour instruction. We have spent almost 8 years refining our curriculum and teaching methods for parkour. To date, the growth of APEX Movement has relied solely on bootstrapping, without any debt or outside investment. Simply put, APEX Movement has always been a labor of love and passion. It has been founded, built, and sustained by freerunners, for freerunners. With your help, we will open up a world class facility to continue to be at the international forefront of parkour and freerunning.Additionally, by contributing you will earn some awesome perks for helping our cause. See the sidebar on the right of this page for details.What We Will Use the Money For
Lumber, metal, and labor costs
Foam to fill our massive, new foam pit
Contractors for an extensive buildout (plumbing, electric, etc.)
Real world obstacles such as I-beams, logs, and ladders
And many more epic surprises!
Other Ways to HelpIf you can’t contribute money, you can still help by sharing this web link with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, or other social media.Copy, paste, and share this link: http://igg.me/at/apex/x/764370Questions?Feel free to send an email to denver@apexmovement.com!Thank You for the SupportWe are grateful for everyone who has supported us over the years. We love our jobs but we wouldn’t be able to do it without all our fantastic members, parents, and staff. It is an honor teaching and moving with every one of you. Prepare yourself for the best parkour gym ever!Your friends in movement,Ryan Ford, Cosmo Dudley, Vinny Fiacco, & the APEX Movement Denver staff

story:
Short Summary

Access to affordable and relevant comprehensive health education are fundamental human rights but gender-based discrimination, lack of access to education, poverty, and violence against women and girls can all prevent these rights from being realized. Single mums and girls face a lot challenges when it comes to sexual reproductive health rights and basic computer skills.

According to the Demographic Health Surveys (2011), it has been revealed that, 21 percent of women and girls have experienced both physical and sexual violence. Though a lot of sensitization has been done to educate women and girls on their rights, there continues to be many cases of violence which are not reported, and therefore, statistics are lower in Cameroonian communities. The Cases of gender-based violence are rampant in Cameroon but only 30 percent of such cases are addressed by the courts. This is because about 60 percent of women and girls are computer literates.

Mother of Hope Cameroon (MOHCAM) in her fight to educate single mums and girls is organizing a three days digital empowerment workshop in the summer to fight against teenage pregnancies and to equip single mums and adolescences on their sexual reproductive health rights and basic computer skills. They will be given the chance to learn leadership skills, build self-confidence and to better understand new marketable skills when using visual training tools. This campaign is aimed at challenging prevalent gender stereotypes in communities, particularly those that reduce the aspirations of girls in rural communities, where traditions are firmest and patriarchal systems still remain very strong. For single mums and girls to fully participate in their communities and enjoy their rights, they need a life free from gender-based discrimination- a life with the opportunity to be educated, to work, to be healthy and to participate in all aspects of public life. However, millions women and girls are frequently beaten, raped, mutilated, killed and subjected to gender violence which limits their opportunities.

What We Need

Our ongoing campaign is working to connect women and girls who are victims of teenage Pregnancies from the rural and underprivileged communities to Virtual Learning Tools. Most of them who are single mums and girls  have never had basic skills in information communication technology due to poverty. If given the opportunity, this will opens doors for them to share information and build like-minded ventures networks. Most rural single mums and girls who are engaged in farming and petite trading will acquire computer skills which will enable them to market their products. They will be able meet with other women and mentors who will direct them in their activities and businesses.

MOHCAM needs $1000 to organize a workshop for three days on sexual reproductive health education and basic computer skills. And $500 to purchase Internet-capable phones  for 30 industrious single mums and girls in the rural communities of Ntasen and Mubang.

There are plenty of steps we can take to strengthen our future, but first we need to take action. We shall be grateful if you would donate  for Internet-capable phones, computers or electronic gadgets to help single mums and girls to learn and even own computers.

The Impact

When Cameroon’s women and girls succeed, Cameroon succeeds!

Women and girls in Cameroon make up more than half of the population. They are the breadwinners and the backbone of our economy, yet they still face harsh treatment due to outdated customs and traditions which hold them back. They are still regarded as their husband’s property, with limited rights in most communities. This workshop will enable them to become local community reporters who can share information and advocate for women’s rights and positive change for everyone.

Equipped with basic computer skills, like-minded people can come together to improve their skills and share their experiences. This will increase productivity and encourage innovation in their businesses and workplace. Togetherness and love will be fostered in young minds, who will then be positioned for the mentoring and training which will enable them to create and contribute to a better economic system in Cameroon.

Most of the girls will become local communicators for victims of violence who can't speak out for the fear of stigmatization in their communities.

1) Many sign mum will be encourage to go back to school.

2) The rate of early teenage pregnancies will reduced and more girls moving to leadership positions.

3) Computers are tools needed by all women and girls for a rapid change! You Can Help!

Risks & Challenges

To enable these positive improvements in our communities, MOHCAM is faced with the challenge to empower 30 single mums and girls out of the thousands of women and girls who are interested in getting the training from Mubang Ntsen Nkwen village. This workshop will take place in Foncha-street Nkwen-Bamenda from the 28th–30th of July 2014 at the Ets.ALMA Cybercafé opposite Providence Clinic due to the lack of electricity and adequate computers.

We intend to extend this training to fresh women and girls entering just universities. Due to the limited Internet access, high school students entering universities in Cameroon are not familiar with the Internet’s power use for research in their studies. Those who go on-line simply use it to send or read emails and chat. These women and girls lack the basic skills to access the vast learning materials available on-line.

Other Ways You Can Help

•  Donate used Internet-capable phones, computers or electronic gadgets to help single mums and girls to learn and even own computers.

•  Use the Indiegogo share tools to promote the project on your web sites and social networks. Invite your family and friends to support the project.

•  Connect us with any foundation that gives in-kind support to charities in Cameroon

•  Discuss the project with your friends and meeting groups

story:
Send kids to college in Mrs. Herder's honor

Diane Herder is retiring after 45 years as a teacher at Laingsburg High School. 

In her debt is everyone who learned to appreciate literature, use new technology, or how to put together a newspaper and a yearbook in her classroom.

"Mrs. Herder" is a brilliant and dedicated professional who chose to dedicate her talents to a rural community and we love her for it. She delivered truly world class education and changed more than a few lives. One way we can help her continue to impact the educational success of Laingsburg students is to set up this scholarship in her name. 

How's this going to work? 

A group of publications room alumni are looking for $5,000 to set up a scholarship fund in Mrs. Herder's honor. 

  • Donations of $5.00 are as important as donations of $500. Mrs. Herder invested in us for 45 years. It's our turn to show her we appreciate it.
  • She's in charge of how to distribute it this year. She  can split it among 5 people. Or, just give it to one student she knows needs financial help and a confidence boost, We trust that 45 years of experience teaches you a thing or two about how to help kids succeed. 
  • We hope there is enough money to seed a scholarship fund drive for many years to come. This group will happily find a home for the scholarship fund within the Laingsburg community so it can continue to make a difference for years to come.
  • If we don't make our goal we'll still hand over the money we make to Mrs. Herder, but let's raise enough to make a real difference for some of Mrs. Herders students!

Other Ways You Can Help

Send this to anybody who knows how much difference Mrs. Herder has made in her 45 year teaching career. Where would we be without her?

story:
Meeting Johanna

My name is Johanna Villasmil, I'm a Venezuelan journalism student and a human right defender, and now I have the opportunity to do an internship with the Organization of American States, an opportunity that will change my life, but only if I have your help.

I became a human rights defender with the help of UNWOMEN and UNICEF. They taught me the importance of this job; they invited me into congresses, forums and internships, and to contribute to on-line publications. I have a blog called “La Expresion del Teenager” (The Expression of a teenager), a space for young people that discusses adult subjects like economy, politics, international problems, governments, and more. I have written a column in a local newspaper for four years and another one for “El Impulso”, the oldest newspaper in Venezuela, for one year. I have a radio show at the Fermín Toro University and had another in a local broadcaster called Intro 90.5. I collaborate directly with LACVOX, a net of UNICEF, and I have worked with them making on-line publications regarding human rights.   


Every day I have gotten more and more involved in human rights. I discovered an amazing world where all of the citizens can be treated in equal form, no matter what gender, religion or age… and that’s what I want for me, my family, my friends, and all the citizens of global community.  At the age of 15, the main point of my blog changed because I thought that we, the teenagers, needed to learn more about international problems, economics, politics, governments and more. Adults tell us that we are the future, but why not act now and be part of the present?. 

My journey to the OAS

I have been selected to do an internship with the Organization of American States from September 11th to December 5th. This is the chance of a lifetime. However, because of the ongoing struggle in my country, I cannot afford the trip and the stay in Washington DC by myself. There is a currency exchange control in Venezuela called CADIVI that regulates the amount of dollars that a Venezuelan can buy when they want to go out of the country, which applies for students too. The proportion of what you can have in dollars is always far below than what you need if they authorize it at all. A lot of people buy US currency in the black market, but at a cost over 6 times higher per dollar. It would take the equivalent of over $33,000 in Venezuelan currency for me to afford the same thing. Paying the rent and tickets is going to be impossible for me without your help. 
I need $5000 to make my dream come true:
  • Plane ticket $1500. Here is the info about the plane ticket 
    • https://bookings.copaair.com/CMGS/AirFareFamiliesForward.do  
  • Rent $3500. Here is the info about costs of the place where I am going to stay  http://ishdc.org/prospective-residents/room-rat... 

About the OAS

The Organization of American States is the world’s oldest regional organization, dating back to the First International Conference of American States, held in Washington, D.C., from October 1889 to April 1890. That meeting approved the establishment of the International Union of American Republics, and the stage was set for the weaving of a web of provisions and institutions that came to be known as the inter-American system, the oldest international institutional system. 

I have high plans for my future and that is why I want to find better opportunities for myself.  My next step towards that future right now is to do this internship with the Organization of American States. But this time, to take that step I need your help. 

    Share it

    If you can't contribute you can still help! please share! 

    • Sometimes a friend is worth all the money in the world. It would be an awesome boost if you simply shared this on twitter or facebook. Eventually, I'll be finding somebody's help thanks to you! The more you help me pass the word around, the closer I'll get to my dream internship in Washington and to continue my journey as a human rights defender.

story:
Short Summary

Hey everyone. First of all thanks for checking out my page. Let me tell you a little bit about Teung Sela. Teung Sela is a girl who currently lives by herself in my office in Phnom Penh. Her family farms a small plot of land far away in Siem Reap province.

Sela is a really kind girl and we've hung out and watched youtube videos together. Everyone around the office has really taken a liking to her and is vested in making sure she's okay and taken care of. Even though she hasn't had enough food for a while she was generous enough to cook for me and share what little food she had when I first got here and was struggling to eat and while I was sick with rheumatic fever.

Sela comes from a poor farming family that lives many miles away that can’t afford to send her to college.  Her dream is to one day go to law school so that she can help fight corruption in Cambodia (which is really, really bad). But, as it currently stands there’s no way she’s going to be able to get the money to go to school for the $570 a year it costs. It's heartbreaking because I know that Sela really wants to go to college and I know if she did she’d spend her life trying to help people.

Her sister used to work for my NGO so as a favor to her everyone here at my office has worked to help put up Sela and give her a place to stay while she goes to high school. Her sister gave her $1000 before she left the country to help pay for her high school fees and food but as the end of high school approaches for Sela she's beginning to realize that she's not going to have enough money to go to university. Sela had actually started budgeting herself to 5000 Cambodian riels a day of food (around $1.25) to help save money to pay for college. Even in Cambodia $1.25 a day is no where near enough to provide proper meals so after having caught wind my country director has been paying for her meals while she stays with us because she had been essentially starving herself for weeks. Unfortunately, even paying for Sela's meals is not enough to help her save the money she needs to go to school. This is where you come in.

The Numbers

  • It costs around $570 a year to send Sela to university
  • It costs around $80 a month to rent a nice apartment in Phnom Penh
  • It also costs money for Sela to eat and get books for school

This means that Sela is going to need upwards of $3000 dollars to make her dream of getting an education a reality.

    The Impact

    Here's exactly what I'm going to do. I currently have exactly $1949.57 in my bank account. I use my money to buy food and pay for medical bills while I'm volunteering in Cambodia. On the day I leave Cambodia (August 26th) I will give the entirety of my bank account along with whatever money is raised here to Sela along with any encouraging messages anyone wants me to pass to Sela.

    I was given a real gift to be able to come to Cambodia and help people. A lot of people can't afford the airfare or for whatever reason can't make it out to parts of the world where people most need help. Most people from poor farming families in Cambodia don't get to go to school. If Sela doesn't get this money she can't go to school and will never be given a chance to make it out of the tiny village she comes from. This is an investment that will change someone's quality of life forever.

    Risks

    If Sela doesn't get enough money then she can't go to school. Sela can only go as far as people are generous.

    Other Ways You Can Help

    If you can't donate money it would be really cool if you could write down some encouraging messages for Sela and send them to me (Jacob.mevorach@trincoll.edu). I'll compile them all into a word document and hand it off to her family when I give them the money.

    Also please share this with as many people as possible! Help me get the word out there so I can help Sela.

 It costs around $80 a month to rent a nice apartment in Phnom Penh
 It also costs money for Sela to eat and get books for school
This means that Sela is going to need upwards of $3000 dollars to make her dream of getting an education a reality.  The Impact Here's exactly what I'm going to do. I currently have exactly $1949.57 in my bank account. I use my money to buy food and pay for medical bills while I'm volunteering in Cambodia. On the day I leave Cambodia (August 26th) I will give the entirety of my bank account along with whatever money is raised here to Sela along with any encouraging messages anyone wants me to pass to Sela.I was given a real gift to be able to come to Cambodia and help people. A lot of people can't afford the airfare or for whatever reason can't make it out to parts of the world where people most need help. Most people from poor farming families in Cambodia don't get to go to school. If Sela doesn't get this money she can't go to school and will never be given a chance to make it out of the tiny village she comes from. This is an investment that will change someone's quality of life forever.  Risks
If Sela doesn't get enough money then she can't go to school. Sela can only go as far as people are generous.  Other Ways You Can HelpIf you can't donate money it would be really cool if you could write down some encouraging messages for Sela and send them to me (Jacob.mevorach@trincoll.edu). I'll compile them all into a word document and hand it off to her family when I give them the money.Also please share this with as many people as possible! Help me get the word out there so I can help Sela.

story:
Building a School in Ethiopia

132 million people live on less than $1 a day. Education provides the strongest opportunity to overcome this level of poverty, however, 72% of school-aged children in Ethiopia do not have access to formal education and we can change that!

How I Got Here

3 years ago my wife and I came to Tapestry Church to team up with great people and help change the world locally and globally.  We've made an impact locally in Savannah, Georgia by being a welcoming church that is open to people from all walks of life. Now the people of Tapestry are reaching across the globe to build a school for those in need.  This December I'll be leading a team from Savannah to the Harar region of Ethiopia to take part in the construction of the school.

Why I need $2500

In short I need your help with travel expenses for:

  • Air-fare
  • Ground Travel
  • Accommodations

More Information 

Tapestry Church is partnering with a group called On The Ground for the actual construction of the school. 

If you would like to learn more about On The Ground you can check out their website here:

On The Ground

If you'd like more information about Tapestry Church you can check out our website here:

Tapestry Church

story:
Thank you for helping us reach our goal. You can continue your support us directly through our website. 

Thank you! http://missionbe.org/donations/

Mission Be has changed many children's lives. Here is one quote from a 2nd grader:
“When you come to my class, I get so exited. I love mindfulness because I am always stressed. I’m always in a rush. I like doing mindfulness everyday because every day I’m stressed. Every time I do mindfulness I feel calm.”  -Julia, grade 2.

After working with children for 15 years and seeing how stressed they are by school work, home and social issues I decided we need a mindful revolution. 18 months later we went from one 2nd grade class on Long Island, New York to 76 classrooms around the world,  training teachers  online as far as Green School in Bali, and Kathmandu Nepal. 

Studies have shown that mindfulness reduces stress and increases focus by up to 30% in school children. Not only that decreases violence by up to 70% because it increases the function of the  part of the brain responsible for empathy! Which means less bullies and less violence. This is why mindfulness is the missing link in social emotional learning. 

Support us now and help us create a digital application with Highground Hackers in San Fran for classrooms around the world. Help us train more educators here in San Fran and in NY to touch the many lives of stressed kids in need of peace around the world. Make the world a better place and support Mission Be. We appreciate all donations and you sharing our mission with your friends. :) Thank you! 

What inspired Mission Be to grow... 

It was the morning of the Sandy Hook school shooting Dec 15th 2012, that I first independently introduced the Mission Be program in 17 classrooms for the first time. When I heard of the heartbreaking and tragic events I knew that children everywhere that experience stress and trauma could benefit from the program I began that day. It was two days later that I started to recruit the 7 incredible women who help me create and implement the first the Mission Be Mindful Education program. 

We worked together and brought the program into the 17 classrooms once a week for 8 weeks and at the end had a mindful art project and school wide Mindful Day for the children, which you can see in the video below. 

Just 18 months later our program has grown to reach 1,400 children a week and we have trained teachers as far as Kathmandu, Nepal and the Green School in Bali. Come support us as we launch our program around the world, create a bicoastal program from the beaches of California to streets of NYC, and help us create a digital mindfulness application and change the heart and minds of children to support a more peaceful world! 


Mission Be

Mindful education workshops and programs emphasizes mindful education, creating peace, increasing learning and improving harmony in school communities.

Mission Be works with schools and communities as well as public and private entities integrating our mindful education program. Mission Be is designed to create positive lasting  cultural changes through the practices of mindfulness, which supports academic growth, nonviolence,  and the cultivation of  compassion.

“When you come to my class, I get so exited. I love mindfulness because I am always stressed. I’m always in a rush. I like the mountain breath because it calms me down the most. I like doing mindfulness everyday because every day I’m stressed. Every time I do mindfulness I feel calm.” – 2nd grader

Mission Be introduces mindfulness through educational endeavors, the use of the arts and multimedia, supportive educational forums, positive dialogue and inter-generational workshops.

What is Mindful Education?

Trained practitioners of this technique are committed to integrating a curriculum where children have the social tools to learn, inspire and grow.  The science of mindful education is reminding children that they effect the world around them and that others effect them. 

“Mindfulness has changed my life.” 4th grader

The building blocks of mindful education are fairness, generosity and the life's breath and compassion. What is special about mindful education is that it is natural and effortless.

Mission Be is run by Carin Winter and a large team of Mindful educators.

“We have changed the culture of our school!” -High School Assistant Principal 

Mindful Education: 8 Weeks of Implementation into the Classroom, Mindful Art Project and Mindful Day

We Create a culture of mindfulness within schools and classrooms by inviting trained master level volunteer mindful educators into classrooms for 8 weeks, for  a weekly 30-40 min lesson based in mindfulness practices designed to create a positive learning environments, increase student focus, decrease bullying, and create a culture of empathy, kindness and understanding.

At the end of the 8 weeks the children create a mindful hero art project in which they paint a national hero, the art is then exhibited and distributed to veterans in local hospitals. On week 10 we have a mindful day which engages the entire school.

Mission Be also created a Trauma Workshop which we just launched in a New York Middle School.

Here is one of our videos for the elementary school:


We are also planning to develop a series of workshops focused on  well-being, character education and  the arts. We are planning:

An Environmental Workshop

A Mindful Music Writing Workshop

Mindful Yoga Series

Mindfulness Workshops for Teens

Join us and check out our rewards: 

Mission Be T-shirt


Gemstone Bracelet



The Story about how we started and our connection to our 501(c)(3) sponsor September's Mission:

I would like to share a miraculous story about our connection to September’s Mission, how we began, and how you can support our incredibly healing and beautifully growing program.

On September 11th, 2001, Michael Iken, beloved husband of Monica Iken, perished in the

World Trade Center. The following Saturday, I met with Monica for the first time. While speaking with her, I had a clear vision of her as a lead spokesperson and advocate for the 9/11 Memorial Project. I actually said, “I see you live on CNN as a spokesperson for a memorial at the WTC. It is your life’s purpose.”  She replied, “That’s impossible. I’m a kindergarten teacher. I love my job and I plan to keep teaching.”

SEPTEMBER’S MISSION

Ten years passed. In the spring of 2011, I saw Monica speaking on CNN live at Ground Zero with President Barack Obama and former Mayor Giuliani. Tears of joy and astonishment filled my eyes. Monica was the CEO of September’s Mission, one of the key organizations representing the families and responsible for the building of the 9/11 Memorial.

Something incredibly powerful and healing had come from all of this devastating destruction. In that moment, I knew in my heart that there was a beautiful force in the world that transcends even the worst of all circumstances. That power is grace and it is transmitted by those who meet tragedy with resilient faith, service, and love.

In the wake of this profound experience, Monica invited me to a preview of the September’s Mission documentary at the Tribeca Film Festival and to visit the 9/11 Memorial. After watching this film:

We walked together to the memorial, standing together at the Memorial, I shared with her my vision for a program designed to decrease violence and cultivate peace in public schools. Monica expressed that this was her intention for phase two of September’s Mission. She advised me to create an outline for curriculum development.

THE YELLOW ROSE

A few months later, I wrote a proposal to share with Monica. The night before our scheduled meeting, I went for a walk on the ocean to pray to God. As I was walking, I came across a perfect long stem yellow rose that had just washed up on the shore.

The next day, I was on my way home from the meeting with Monica in Manhattan when I hopped on the wrong train at Jamaica station. The conductor made an unscheduled stop for me. Incredibly, he also arranged for a second train to stop, just to pick me up. When I stepped off that train, there in front of me was the new poster for the 9/11 Memorial. To my great astonishment, the poster featured a yellow rose much like the one washed up on the shore the previous day.

 The Rose Poster

It is the power of love and grace in our lives that make miracles happen. Monica fulfilled her calling, and I am honored to heed my own: to lead the creation and implementation of a powerful program that radically touches the hearts of young people. We at Mission Be will fulfill phase two of this heartfelt mission.

story:
About Us:

Visionary is an independent color guard from the South Shore of Massachusetts, under the support of Bandmasters Youth & Arts Organization and is based out of the Rockland/Brockton area. We compete nationally in WGI (Winter Guard International - "The Sport of the Arts") and locally in NESBA (The New England Scholastic Band Association) circuits.

Being an independent group means that we are not affiliated with the local school district and we rely on fund-raising efforts (we hold several fundraisers throughout the year) & membership dues to support our program. While this does allow us to partially fund our program, sadly it does not cover everything.  Our biggest expense is the cost of rehearsal space. We currently rent a school gym to be able to practice & create our show pieces. Other costs include equipment, uniforms, transportation, competition entrance fees, etc. Many of our students come from middle or low income families, so financial support is not always readily available. 

This is where you come in! We are looking to raise funds to help our program succeed. Would you please consider making a donation to our program? Every little bit helps! If everyone on your FB friends list donated just $1.00, we could raise the money in no time! Even if you are unable to financially contribute, just sharing our page with your family & friends would be greatly appreciated!

Thank you for your time & effort from the bottom of our hearts.

story:
English, Castellano, Português, Français

 

The Young Feminists' Camp

The Young Feminists' Camp is an initiative born out of the European coordination of the World March of Women, a global movement connecting grassroots groups and organizations to fight patriarchy, exploitation and gender violence faced by women in the world. The idea of the camp is to build a network and solidarity among different women and feminists in Europe and globally in order to make our fight stronger and more sustainable.

We started out with our first camp in 2011 in Toulouse, France where approximately 70 young feminists from France, Romania, Switzerland, Armenia, Germany, Basque Country, Belgium, Macedonia, Portugal, Poland and other countries in Europe attended. The aim of this camp was to make connections with women sharing similar struggles and to become stronger in uniting those struggles. In addition to many helpful workshops to learn about women's situations in different countries as well as learning various skills and tools to help us in the women's movements of our individual countries, we also had a demonstration in downtown Toulouse. We gave voice to the different struggles we work in our lives including abortion rights, austerity, violence against women, racism, homo-lesbo-transphobia, climate change, and so on.

We met again in Romania in 2012 for the second Young Feminists' Camp with a more expanded network including women from Chile, Brazil, Turkey and several European feminists joining for the first time. Once again we had a successful camp, which led to a number of future collective actions and projects. You can visit our blog to find out more: http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/

Our network has grown and expanded since our first camp in 2011 and we want to grow more. We need your help to meet once again this year in August. This time we will be meeting in Portugal, where the troika – the alliance composed by the IMF, European Comission and European Central Bank - together with the national government that supports its politics have been devastating the country for the past two years. 

This year we would like to continue expanding by including more eastern European countries such as Bosnia Herzegovina, Croatia, Bulgaria, Montenegro, etc. as well as to invite women from the Philippines, Tunisia, and Kenya. We believe that it is important to connect women across difficult political and cultural boundaries in order to break those that have been built within each of us to keep us down and divided.

Unemployment, precariousness and poverty has been growing and mortgaging the lives of most people, including thousands of women. The right to health and sexual and reproductive rights are increasingly becoming a mirage for many of us. In the last ten years Portugal was one of the only European countries to see the wage gap between men and women increase. Gender based violence has also been growing and intensifying.

While in previous years we were funded by the European Union's Youth in Action Program, it is uncertain whether we will get this support again this year.We feel that this camp has been a crucial moment in our lives as women fighting to end violence and injustice in our individual lives, communities and countries. We have had our struggles reaffirmed, made stronger and connected to the struggles of other women through the Young Feminists' Camps of the past two years. And we believe it is important to continue meeting, sharing ideas and struggles, successes and failures, engaging in difficult conversations, breaking stereotypes and collaborating to move the world powerfully forward for all women.

Your contribution will allow us to meet in August and continue building this movement. By donating you also become part of the movement to end violence, poverty, racism, homo-lesbo-transphobia, and all injustices suffered by women in our different countries. If we reach our full goal, we will be able to invite women from more countries outside of Europe to join our collective struggles and become even stronger in our unity. If we don'treach our goal we will be able to...

7 000€ Camp for 30 people without reimbursement of travel costs.

10 000€ - Camp for 60 people without reimbursement of travel costs.

15 000€ - Camp for 60 people with reimbursement of some travels.

25 000€ - Camp for 60 people with reimbursement of 70% of all travel costs.

 

El Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas

 

El Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas es una iniciativa que nació de la coordinación Europea de la Marcha Mundial de las Mujeres, se trata de un movimiento global que reúne grupos de base y organizaciones de lucha contra el patriarcado, la explotación y la violencia de género que las mujeres experimentan en todo el mundo. La idea del campamento es la de construir una red de solidaridad entre mujeres y feministas de Europa y todo el mundo  con el propósito de dar más fuerza a nuestra lucha y hacerla más  sostenible.
Nuestra andadura comenzó con el primer campamento en 2011, en Toulouse, Francia, donde participaron  unas 70 jóvenes feministas de Francia, Rumanía, Suiza, Armenia, Alemania, País Vasco, Bélgica, Macedonia, Portugal, Polonia y otros países de Europa. El objetivo de este campamento fue el de establecer vínculos más estrechos entre mujeres que comparten las mismas dificultades y luchas, y el de fortalecer este movimiento de jóvenes feministas.  Igualmente se impartieron varios talleres a través de los cuales pudimos acercarnos a la situación de las mujeres en diferentes países y dónde aprendimos el manejo de diversos métodos y técnicas para empoderar los distintos movimientos nacionales, además también hicimos una acción-protesta en el centro de Touluose. Dimos voz a las distintas luchas que enfrentamos en nuestras vidas, como el derecho al aborto, la austeridad, la violencia contra las mujeres, el racismo, la homofobia, el cambio climático, etc.
Nos volvimos a reunir en Rumanía, en 2012, para el segundo Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas, ya con una red más extensa que incluyó mujeres procedentes de Chile, Brasil y Turquía, así como algunas  feministas europeas que se nos unieron por primera vez, y de nuevo, esta experiencia que desencadenó proyectos y acciones colectivas fue un gran éxito.

 Puedes visitar nuestro blog para saber más: http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/


Nuestra red creció y se expandió desde el primer campamento en 2011 y queremos crecer aún más. Necesitamos tu ayuda para encontrarnos de nuevo en agosto de este año. Esta vez, el encuentro tendrá lugar en Portugal, donde la Troika (compuesta por el FMI, la Comisión Europea y el Banco Central Europeo) y el Gobierno que la apoya, están devastando el país. En los últimos 10 años, Portugal fue el único país donde aumentó la desigualdad salarial.

Este año, nos gustaría seguir extendiendo nuestra red, para incluir a más países del Este, como Bosnia Herzegovina, Croacia, Bulgaria, Montenegro, etc., así como invitar a mujeres de las Filipinas, Túnez y Kenia. Creemos que es importante unir a las mujeres a través de las fronteras políticas y culturales para lograr romper esas barreras que nos mantienen divididas y subyugadas. La violencia de género crece y se intensifica, el desempleo, la precariedad  y la pobreza siguen aumentando e hipotecando la vida de la mayoría de la población mundial y donde se incluye la vida de millones de mujeres. El derecho a la salud, a los derechos sexuales y reproductivos son cada vez más un espejismo para muchas de nosotras.

Mientras en años precedentes fuimos financiadas por el programa Juventud en Acción de la Unión Europea, este año es aún incierto si volveremos a tener este apoyo. Sentimos que este campamento ha sido un momento crucial en nuestras vidas, en cuanto que reúne a mujeres que luchan por el fin de la violencia y de la injusticia en nuestras vidas. A través de los Campamentos Feministas en los últimos dos años, hemos reafirmado y unido nuestra lucha lo que nos ha hecho más fuertes, por lo que creemos que es importante seguir reuniéndose, compartiendo ideas y luchas, sucesos y fracasos, envolviéndonos en discusiones difíciles, rompiendo con estereotipos y poniendo nuestro granito de arena para lograr un mundo más igualitario y justo donde consigamos el efectivo empoderamiento de la vida de las mujeres.

Al donar, no sólo haces un aporte económico, si no que también apoyas a un movimiento que pretende acabar con la violencia, la pobreza, el racismo, la homo-lesbo-transfobia y todas las injusticias que sufren las mujeres en distintas partes del mundo. Si alcanzamos nuestro objetivo, seremos capaces de invitar a mujeres de otros países de fuera de Europa para que se juntan nuestras luchas y de esta manera dar más eco a nuestra voz y hacernos cada vez más fuertes.

7 000€ Campamento para 30 personas sin financiamiento de viajes.
10 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas sin financiamiento de viajes.
15 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas con financiamiento de algunos viajes
25 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas con financiamiento de 70% de todos los viajes.

 

Acampamento de Jovens Feministas

O Acampamento de Jovens Feministas é uma iniciativa da coordenação europeia da Marcha Mundial das Mulheres, um movimento global, que conecta organizações e grupos de base no combate ao patriarcado, à exploração e à violência de género enfrentadas pelas mulheres em todo o mundo. A ideia do acampamento é construir uma rede e fomentar a solidariedade entre diferentes mulheres e feministas, na Europa e globalmente, com vista a fortalecer a nossa luta e torná-la mais sustentável.

O primeiro acampamento teve lugar em Toulouse, França, em 2011, no qual participaram aproximadamente 70 jovens feministas vindas de França, Roménia, Suíça, Arménia, Alemanha, País Basco, Bélgica, Macedónia, Portugal, entre outros países europeus. O acampamento teve como objectivo criar sinergias entre mulheres que partilham lutas semelhantes e fortalecer o movimento unindo essas lutas. Além de vários workshops com vista a conhecer a situação de mulheres nos diferentes países, assim como oficinas para aprender várias competências e instrumentos para nos apoiar nos movimentos de mulheres nos nossos países, também fizemos uma demonstração no centro de Toulouse. Demos voz às diferentes lutas que enfrentamos nas nossas vidas, tais como direito ao aborto, luta contra a austeridade, violência contra as mulheres, racismo, homo-lesbo-transfobia, alterações climáticas, entre outras.

Encontrámo-nos de novo na Roménia, em 2012, para o segundo Acampamento de Jovens Feministas, desta vez com um rede mais alargada de participantes, incluindo mulheres do Chile, Brasil e Turquia e feministas europeias que se juntaram a nós pela primeira vez. Mais uma vez, o acampamento foi um sucesso, levando à realização de vários projectos e acções colectivas posteriores. Podes encontrar mais informação em: http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/

A nossa rede tem vindo a crescer e a expandir-se desde o primeiro acampamento em 2011 e queremos crescer ainda mais. Precisamos da tua ajuda de modo a podermo-nos encontrar, mais uma vez, em Agosto. Desta feita iremos encontrar-nos em Portugal, onde a Troika (composta pelo FMI, pela Comissão Europeia e pelo Banco Central Europeu) e o governo que a apoia tem vindo a devastar o país nos últimos 2 anos.

Gostaríamos de, este ano, poder continuar a expandir a nossa rede incluindopaíses do leste da Europa, tais como a Bósnia Herzegovina, a Croácia, a Bulgária e o Montenegro, entre outros, convidando, também, mulheres das Filipinas, Tunísia e Quénia. Acreditamos que é importante conectar mulheres entre fronteiras políticas e culturais de modo a quebrar as barreiras, construídas dentro de cada uma de nós, que nos mantêm passivas e divididas.

O desemprego, a precariedade e a pobreza têm vindo a crescer, hipotecando as vidas da maior parte da população, incluindo milhares de mulheres. O direito à saúde e os direitos sexuais e reprodutivos vão-se gradualmente tornando uma miragem para muitas de nós. Nos últimos 10 anosPortugal foi um dos únicos países europeus que viu a diferença de salários entre homens e mulheres aumentar. A violência de género também tem vindo a crescer e intensificar-se.

Enquanto que, nos anos anteriores, obtivemos financiamento da União Europeia para a realização do acampamento,através do programa Juventude em Acção, é ainda incertose conseguiremoseste apoio para este ano. Sentimos que este acampamento tem sido crucial nas nossas vidas enquanto mulheres que lutam para pôr fim à violência e à injustiça nas nossas vidas individuais, nas nossas comunidades e nos nossos países. Através do Acampamento de Jovens Feministas dos últimos dois anos reafirmamos as nossas lutas, fortalecemo-nos e conectamo-nos com as lutas de outras mulheres. E acreditamos que é importante continuarmos a encontrar-nos, a partilhar ideias e lutas, sucessos e derrotas, a estabelecer conversas difíceis, a quebrar estereótipos e a colaborar para fazer o mundo avançar, empoderando todas as mulheres.

A tua contribuição irá permitir-nos encontrarmo-nos em Agosto e continuar a construir este movimento. Ao fazer um donativo estarás também a participar deste movimento que luta pelo fim da violência, da pobreza, do racismo, da homo-lesbo-transfobia e de todas as injustiças sofridas pelas mulheres nos nossos países. Se alcançarmos a nossa meta, ser-nos-à possível convidar mulheres de outros países fora da Europa para, assim, juntarmos as nossas lutas colectivas, tornando-as ainda mais fortes na sua unidade. Se não conseguirmos o nosso objectivo:

7 000€ Acampamento para 30 pessoas sem  financiamento de viagens.

10 000€ - Acampamento  para 60 pessoas.sem financiamento de viagens

15 000€ - Acampamento para 60 pessoas com financiamento  de algumas viagens

25 000€ - Acampamento para 60 pessoas com financiamento de 70% de todas as viagens.

 

 Le Campement de Jeunes Féministes

 

Le Campement de Jeunes Féministes est une initiative de la Coordination européenne de la Marche Mondiale des Femmes, un mouvement social mondial qui rassemble des groupes de femmes de la base, pour lutter contre le patriarcat, l’exploitation et les violences subies par les femmes dans le monde. L’idée du campement est de construire un réseau et de la solidarité entre jeunes femmes féministes d’Europe  et globalement pour rendre notre combat plus fort et durable.

Nous avons commencé avec le 1er campement en 2011 près de Toulouse en France, où environ 70 jeunes féministes de France, Roumanie, Suisse, Arménie, Allemagne, Pays Basque, Belgique, Macédoine, Portugal, Pologne et d’autres pays d’Europe ont participé. Le but du campement était de se rencontrer avec des jeunes femmes partageant les mêmes luttes et pour être plus fortes en unissant ces luttes. Il y a eu de nombreux ateliers autour de la situation des femmes dans les différents pays et permettant d’apprendre différents outils et techniques pour nous aider dans les mouvements de femmes. Nous avons aussi fait une manifestation dans la ville de Toulouse et rédigé un Manifeste commun. Nous avons donné de la voix à différentes luttes dans lesquelles nous sommes engagées comme le droit à l’avortement, contre l’austérité, les violences contre les femmes, le racisme, l’homo-lesbo-transphobie, le changement climatique, etc.

On s’est retrouvées en 2012 en Roumanie pour le deuxième Campement de Jeunes Féministes d’Europe avec un plus grand réseau incluant des femmes du Chili, du Brésil, de Turquie et de nombreuses féministes d’Europe venant pour la 1ère fois. De nouveau nous avons eu un super campement, qui nous a amené à plusieurs projets et actions collectives. Vous pouvez en savoir plus sur notre blog : http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/

Notre réseau a grandi et s’est développé depuis notre premier campement en 2011 et nous voulons continuer de grandir. Nous avons besoin de votre aide pour nous rencontrer une nouvelle fois en Aout cette année. Cette fois, nous nous rencontrerons au Portugal, où la troika – l’alliance du FMI, de la Commission européenne et de la Banque Centrale Européenne – avec les gouvernements qui soutiennent leur politique a dévasté le pays depuis 2 ans.

Cette année nous voulons continuer à nous étendre en incluant plus de pays d’Europe de l’est comme la Bosnie Hérzegovine, la Croatie, la Bulgarie, le Montenegro … et pous inviter des femmes des Philippines, de Tunisie et du Kenya. Nous croyons qu’il est important de mettre en lien les femmes malgrè les difficultés politiques et les barrières culturelles afin de briser celles qui ont été construites entre nous pour nous garder faibles et divisées.

Le chômage, la précarité et la pauvreté ont augmenté, hypothéquant la vie de la plupart des gens, et notamment de millions de femmes. Le droit à la santé sexuelle et reproductive devient de plus en plus un mirage pour nombre d’entre nous. Le Portugal est un des seuls pays européens à avoir vu la différence entre les salaires des hommes et ceux des femmes augmenter. Les violences faites aux femmes ont aussi augmentées et se sont intensifiées.

Alors que les années précédentes, nous étions financées par le programme Jeunesse de l’Union Européenne, notre financement de cette année est encore incertain. Nous savons que ces campements ont été des moments cruciaux dans nos vies de jeunes femmes en lutte pour mettre fin aux violences et aux injustices dans nos vies, nos communautés, nos pays. Nous avons vu nos luttes réaffirmées, rendues plus fortes et connectées aux luttes des autres jeunes femmes du réseau des Jeunes Féministes d’Europe des campements des 2 dernières années. Et nous croyons qu’il est important de continuer de se rencontrer, de partager des idées et des exemples de luttes, des succès et des échecs, d’engager encore des conversations parfois difficiles entre nous, de casser les stéréotypes et de collaborer pour rendre le monde meilleur pour toutes les femmes.

Votre contribution nous permettra de nous rencontrer en aout et de continuer de construire le mouvement. En donnant, vous faites aussi part de ce mouvement qui travaille pour en finir avec la pauvreté, le racisme, l’homo-lebo et transphobie, et avec toutes les injustices subies par les femmes dans les différents pays. Si nous atteignons notre objectif de budget, nous pourrons inviter des femmes d’autres pays en dehors d’Europe pour rejoindre nos luttes collectives et devenir plus fortes dans l’unité. Si nous n’atteignons pas totalement notre but, nous pourrons …

7 000€ Campement pour 30 jeunes femmes sans remboursement des voyages

10 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes sans remboursement des voyages

15 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes avec remboursement de certains voyages

25 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes avec remboursement de 70% des voyages pour toutes.
story_txt:
English, Castellano, Português, Français
 
The Young Feminists' Camp
The Young Feminists' Camp is an initiative born out of the European coordination of the World March of Women, a global movement connecting grassroots groups and organizations to fight patriarchy, exploitation and gender violence faced by women in the world. The idea of the camp is to build a network and solidarity among different women and feminists in Europe and globally in order to make our fight stronger and more sustainable.
We started out with our first camp in 2011 in Toulouse, France where approximately 70 young feminists from France, Romania, Switzerland, Armenia, Germany, Basque Country, Belgium, Macedonia, Portugal, Poland and other countries in Europe attended. The aim of this camp was to make connections with women sharing similar struggles and to become stronger in uniting those struggles. In addition to many helpful workshops to learn about women's situations in different countries as well as learning various skills and tools to help us in the women's movements of our individual countries, we also had a demonstration in downtown Toulouse. We gave voice to the different struggles we work in our lives including abortion rights, austerity, violence against women, racism, homo-lesbo-transphobia, climate change, and so on.
We met again in Romania in 2012 for the second Young Feminists' Camp with a more expanded network including women from Chile, Brazil, Turkey and several European feminists joining for the first time. Once again we had a successful camp, which led to a number of future collective actions and projects. You can visit our blog to find out more: http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/
Our network has grown and expanded since our first camp in 2011 and we want to grow more. We need your help to meet once again this year in August. This time we will be meeting in Portugal, where the troika – the alliance composed by the IMF, European Comission and European Central Bank - together with the national government that supports its politics have been devastating the country for the past two years. 
This year we would like to continue expanding by including more eastern European countries such as Bosnia Herzegovina, Croatia, Bulgaria, Montenegro, etc. as well as to invite women from the Philippines, Tunisia, and Kenya. We believe that it is important to connect women across difficult political and cultural boundaries in order to break those that have been built within each of us to keep us down and divided.
Unemployment, precariousness and poverty has been growing and mortgaging the lives of most people, including thousands of women. The right to health and sexual and reproductive rights are increasingly becoming a mirage for many of us. In the last ten years Portugal was one of the only European countries to see the wage gap between men and women increase. Gender based violence has also been growing and intensifying.
While in previous years we were funded by the European Union's Youth in Action Program, it is uncertain whether we will get this support again this year.We feel that this camp has been a crucial moment in our lives as women fighting to end violence and injustice in our individual lives, communities and countries. We have had our struggles reaffirmed, made stronger and connected to the struggles of other women through the Young Feminists' Camps of the past two years. And we believe it is important to continue meeting, sharing ideas and struggles, successes and failures, engaging in difficult conversations, breaking stereotypes and collaborating to move the world powerfully forward for all women.
Your contribution will allow us to meet in August and continue building this movement. By donating you also become part of the movement to end violence, poverty, racism, homo-lesbo-transphobia, and all injustices suffered by women in our different countries. If we reach our full goal, we will be able to invite women from more countries outside of Europe to join our collective struggles and become even stronger in our unity. If we don'treach our goal we will be able to...
7 000€ Camp for 30 people without reimbursement of travel costs.
10 000€ - Camp for 60 people without reimbursement of travel costs.
15 000€ - Camp for 60 people with reimbursement of some travels.
25 000€ - Camp for 60 people with reimbursement of 70% of all travel costs.
 
El Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas
 
El Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas es una iniciativa que nació de la coordinación Europea de la Marcha Mundial de las Mujeres, se trata de un movimiento global que reúne grupos de base y organizaciones de lucha contra el patriarcado, la explotación y la violencia de género que las mujeres experimentan en todo el mundo. La idea del campamento es la de construir una red de solidaridad entre mujeres y feministas de Europa y todo el mundo  con el propósito de dar más fuerza a nuestra lucha y hacerla más  sostenible. Nuestra andadura comenzó con el primer campamento en 2011, en Toulouse, Francia, donde participaron  unas 70 jóvenes feministas de Francia, Rumanía, Suiza, Armenia, Alemania, País Vasco, Bélgica, Macedonia, Portugal, Polonia y otros países de Europa. El objetivo de este campamento fue el de establecer vínculos más estrechos entre mujeres que comparten las mismas dificultades y luchas, y el de fortalecer este movimiento de jóvenes feministas.  Igualmente se impartieron varios talleres a través de los cuales pudimos acercarnos a la situación de las mujeres en diferentes países y dónde aprendimos el manejo de diversos métodos y técnicas para empoderar los distintos movimientos nacionales, además también hicimos una acción-protesta en el centro de Touluose. Dimos voz a las distintas luchas que enfrentamos en nuestras vidas, como el derecho al aborto, la austeridad, la violencia contra las mujeres, el racismo, la homofobia, el cambio climático, etc. Nos volvimos a reunir en Rumanía, en 2012, para el segundo Campamento de Jóvenes Feministas, ya con una red más extensa que incluyó mujeres procedentes de Chile, Brasil y Turquía, así como algunas  feministas europeas que se nos unieron por primera vez, y de nuevo, esta experiencia que desencadenó proyectos y acciones colectivas fue un gran éxito.
 Puedes visitar nuestro blog para saber más: http://youngfeministcamp.wordpress.com/
 Nuestra red creció y se expandió desde el primer campamento en 2011 y queremos crecer aún más. Necesitamos tu ayuda para encontrarnos de nuevo en agosto de este año. Esta vez, el encuentro tendrá lugar en Portugal, donde la Troika (compuesta por el FMI, la Comisión Europea y el Banco Central Europeo) y el Gobierno que la apoya, están devastando el país. En los últimos 10 años, Portugal fue el único país donde aumentó la desigualdad salarial.
Este año, nos gustaría seguir extendiendo nuestra red, para incluir a más países del Este, como Bosnia Herzegovina, Croacia, Bulgaria, Montenegro, etc., así como invitar a mujeres de las Filipinas, Túnez y Kenia. Creemos que es importante unir a las mujeres a través de las fronteras políticas y culturales para lograr romper esas barreras que nos mantienen divididas y subyugadas. La violencia de género crece y se intensifica, el desempleo, la precariedad  y la pobreza siguen aumentando e hipotecando la vida de la mayoría de la población mundial y donde se incluye la vida de millones de mujeres. El derecho a la salud, a los derechos sexuales y reproductivos son cada vez más un espejismo para muchas de nosotras.
Mientras en años precedentes fuimos financiadas por el programa Juventud en Acción de la Unión Europea, este año es aún incierto si volveremos a tener este apoyo. Sentimos que este campamento ha sido un momento crucial en nuestras vidas, en cuanto que reúne a mujeres que luchan por el fin de la violencia y de la injusticia en nuestras vidas. A través de los Campamentos Feministas en los últimos dos años, hemos reafirmado y unido nuestra lucha lo que nos ha hecho más fuertes, por lo que creemos que es importante seguir reuniéndose, compartiendo ideas y luchas, sucesos y fracasos, envolviéndonos en discusiones difíciles, rompiendo con estereotipos y poniendo nuestro granito de arena para lograr un mundo más igualitario y justo donde consigamos el efectivo empoderamiento de la vida de las mujeres.
Al donar, no sólo haces un aporte económico, si no que también apoyas a un movimiento que pretende acabar con la violencia, la pobreza, el racismo, la homo-lesbo-transfobia y todas las injusticias que sufren las mujeres en distintas partes del mundo. Si alcanzamos nuestro objetivo, seremos capaces de invitar a mujeres de otros países de fuera de Europa para que se juntan nuestras luchas y de esta manera dar más eco a nuestra voz y hacernos cada vez más fuertes.
7 000€ Campamento para 30 personas sin financiamiento de viajes. 10 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas sin financiamiento de viajes. 15 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas con financiamiento de algunos viajes 25 000€ - Campamento para 60 personas con financiamiento de 70% de todos los viajes.
 

Acampamento de Jovens Feministas

Votre contribution nous permettra de nous rencontrer en aout et de continuer de construire le mouvement. En donnant, vous faites aussi part de ce mouvement qui travaille pour en finir avec la pauvreté, le racisme, l’homo-lebo et transphobie, et avec toutes les injustices subies par les femmes dans les différents pays. Si nous atteignons notre objectif de budget, nous pourrons inviter des femmes d’autres pays en dehors d’Europe pour rejoindre nos luttes collectives et devenir plus fortes dans l’unité. Si nous n’atteignons pas totalement notre but, nous pourrons …
7 000€ Campement pour 30 jeunes femmes sans remboursement des voyages
10 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes sans remboursement des voyages
15 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes avec remboursement de certains voyages
25 000€ - Campement pour 60 jeunes femmes avec remboursement de 70% des voyages pour toutes.

story:
Why You Should Care About This Music Scholarship Program. 

Founded in 1995, the Noel Pointer Foundation (NPF) is a not-for-profit that dramatically enriches children's lives by providing New York inner-city communities with:

  • professional string music education
  • performance opportunities
  • college placement assistance

Through this crowd-funding campaign, YOU have the opportunity to help NPF grant up to 50 disadvanteged students with an instrument and 26 weeks (Sept 2013-June 2014) of professional instruction in their choice of:

  • violin
  • viola
  • cello
  • piano
  • double bass
  • classical guitar

At NPF, we are in the business of uplifting underserved communities through music education. Defining new ways to fund scholarships for the most disadvantaged among us is of the highest priority. We hope that it is for you too. Please donate now.

Why Your Donation Matters Now More Then Ever

Due to money spent supporting the victims of Hurricane Sandy last year (a very noble cause), the Brooklyn Community Foundation will not be able to support this crucial music enrichment program in 2013-14. BUT YOU CAN HELP! YOUR DONATION WILL ALLOW US TO CONTINUE PROVIDING THESE YOUNG MUSICIANS IN-THE-MAKING WITH NEW POSSIBILITIES!

The Scholarship Process

Annually, NPF offers $50,000 worth of need-based financial aid for up to 50 students (ages 4-18). Through a highly detailed application process, NPF determines what families have the greatest need. Those selected will be provided with a discount of 25% to 100% on tuition to the NPF School of Music. Every cent raised through Indiegogo (whether we reach our goal or not) will be put towards this financial aid assistance.

How You're Going To Change Lives With Your Donation

NPF’s ultimate goal is to provide our students with brighter career opportunities. Teaching Artists act as mentors, creating an environment of accomplishment for their students. The discipline, patience and self-worth born from this environment is reflected in future student accomplishments. 20 out of 35 students were accepted into specialized, art related schools including Brooklyn High School for the Arts, Mark Twain School for the Gifted, Frank Sinatra School for the Arts and Laguardia High School for Music. Recent successes include sophomore viola student, Jerusha, receiving a full scholarship to attend Point, Counter Point Chamber Music Camp for the Summer of 2013. After only 1 year of study, violin student Pilar was awarded a Medal of Excellence from Carnegie Hall in February of 2013. The New York Department of Education recently requested a special concert by NPF music students from PS9 due to their incredible progress. NPF alumni can be found attending Juilliard, NYU, & Brandeis University, to name a few. These are the types of gifts your donation provides for these very deserving kids.

What You Get

  • A very public thank you via social media
  • Free publicity on noelpointer.org
  • NPF Swag
  • Tickets to exclusive V.I.P. events
  • & More

See the boxes to the right for details!

Give in 4 Easy Steps

  1. Choose which perks you want from the menu to the right. 
  2. Click the "Contribute Now" button.
  3. Make your donation on a fully secure webpage
  4. Feel really good about yourself.

NOTE: you can give any amount you wish. The totals listed are the minimum to receive each perk.

You're Important & Sharing is Caring

Make some noise about this new fundraising campaign! Recruit people by simply using the sharing tools below.
