story:
Short Summary

Social injustice has been a huge topic in the "Western world" for years now - our governments have heard about it, people are aware and trying to change things. There are all sorts of programs to support disadvantaged people. In many other countries it is up to each inividual to finance basic schooling - many children have to earn money or beg to help the family to buy food.

I just graduated high school and I want to make a change. I know I cannot change the world, but I will certainly change the world of those I work with and for.

I will teach English and Maths to Indonesian kids in a project called "children's oasis" in a village calles Jagaraga on Lombok. The local kids go there to learn and to spend their day sheltered rather than on the streets. The children get to play and make music together, they can do handicrafts and learn.
The idea of the project is to help the villagers help themselves. Eventually good education is the only way to enhance the overall structure in poor villages. Education is the key to good working conditions, to further education and to any kind of change. Education is the key to a better tomorrow.

I believe this world could be a lot better if everybody contributed as much as they can. I had the privilege to be born in a country that offers education to everybody. I now want to take some time and spread the blessing - I want to educate people, who then will be able to teach others who again will be able to educate more and more people.

I would be very greatful if you'd decide to help educate the children in Jagarage, Lombok, Indonesia. No child should be left behind because they were born in the so called "third world" - every child deserves to grow up in a safe environment, to learn and to grow freely.

What Is Needed & What You Get

Funding is needed for maintenance of the existing buildings but also for a new project connecting to the Oasis: There is a house being built for the older kids (15+). Rather than sending them back to the streets once they are old enough to live by themselves they shall live together in a living community. Together they shall learn how to use what they have learned in the Oasis, together they shall start their own social projects, together they shall live in a friendly community where everybody is appreciated for their individual talents and thoughts.
I will live together with those teenagers for 12 months. I will leave Germany on August 20th and will return in August 2014. I will live in the living community with the Indonesian kids.
Funding is also needed for ongoing expenses (material for crafting, sports equipment,...) and for some special events or expenses (baking day, soccer match, new tomato plants for the yard,...)
If you decide to fund this campaign your money will go straight to the project. My flight, insurance, vaccinations etc. are already funded so each penny will go right to the project - to the street children in Jagaraga.
Indonesia as a country is gorgeous. The landscape is incredible and the people are beautiful. During my stay I will take many photos, which I will post online. Each distributor gets to pick one of the photos posted, which will be sent to them. And don't worry - the photos are well worth it - I have taken many great ones already.
Of course a photo is not "worth" as much as your contribution, but you'll get a picture of what you are supporting. Investing in child education is investing in a better future, investing in change. Knowing that you help a child live the life they want is probably the biggest thing you get from funding this project.

The Impact

Your contribution helps to ensure that the "children's oasis" won't have to shut its doors at some point of time. The Oasis aims to educate a whole generation of village children who will help to enhance the standard of living of the entire village.

It is important to fight inequalities all over the world. As there's injustice in each and every country the international inqualities are much bigger. We need to help developing countries to develop so that one day the world we live on will not be seperated in the first and third world, but will shine as one world.

Education is the key to a better tomorrow. On the long term education is the only way out of poverty, which is why I am donating a whole year to Jagaraga and asking you to donate some money.
 
Yes, the village is small, there are thousands of poor villages and the Oasis is only active in one of them. Some might say the work will never show any effect. And it won't from a global point of view. But it changes the world of the children that are being taught. It's a great opportunity for each and everyone of them. Growing up in the Oasis rather than in the desert of poverty, exploition, drugs and prostitution should be granted to every child. Please help to change some children's worlds!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't support the Oasis financially prayers are always welcome. It would also be a great help if you'd "Share" the campaign on your facebook, via Twitter, google+ or any other site. Or if you'd tell your friends about the Oasis. Maybe you could even talk about it in your church and ask for donations.
Any kind of help is highly appreciated!
Thank you very much for reading through the project description!

story:
Short Summary

I am a PhD student in Geography at Penn State University, researching cross-border cattle trade in Ethiopia, Djibouti and Saudi Arabia.  Pastoralism plays an important role in the economic growth of Africa. Across the continent, an estimated 50 million livestock producers support their families, their communities, and a massive meat, skins and hides industry based on cattle and other livestock.  

Nomadic pastoralists in Africa are known to move their herds across international borders in search of new grazing or for trade. Although this trade helps lower food prices, increase food security, relieve border tensions and promote regional integration,  there are also risks due to the unregulated and undocumented nature of this trade. Such risks may include the spread of disease, unequal market access and drastic changes in cattle price. 

My research will involve 'on the ground' interviews and observations along the cattle commodity chain beginning with cattle production in Ethiopia and quarantine in Djibouti and ending with the Saudi export market.  

I have already been awarded a scholarship that covers my travel and research activities, but this funding only covers expenses for me.  As I follow the cow from Ethiopia to Djibouti to Saudi Arabia, please help fund my son's portion so that he may also gain a global perspective on some of the world's most challenging issues.

What We Need & What You Get

In order for Farris to travel to Ethiopia and Djibouti with me for three weeks in July, we need to raise $2500.  This will help cover his passport, visas and shots, as well as his meals and airfare. If the above amount is not raised by mid June, I will reserve the raised funds for my next trip to Ethiopia and Djibouti in November.

The Impact

This opportunity will expose him to cultures, livelihoods and physical environments that are, in some cases, far different from and, in other cases, very similar to those here in the US. I want him to experience that for himself, share what he learns with his peers and develop personally into a global leader. I also hope to use this experience of traveling abroad with my son as a training opportunity to help many other kids experience service learning and research in developing countries.

Other Ways You Can Help

Any donation amount is welcome.  If you are unable to contribute financially, you can help a great deal by making some noise about this campaign using Indiegogo share tools.

Thank you!!!

Chanda Turner

story:
Photo is where I will be living on the San Marco gate wall in Siena. 

 

What I am doing

My name is Charolette Stoehr. I am 47 years old and a junior at Portland State University. I have the opportunity to study abroad in Italy for a term. This has been a dream of mine all of my life. I am a late bloomer for a college education but I have always known I would go back to school after my kids were grown. I have been studying creative writing, photography, drawing, music, painting and art history. By some divine universal gift, I received a Gilman award  to study abroad. I applied as a dream pie in the sky type of thing and now I am packing up my apartment to go live in Italy for 12 weeks. The study abroad program is called Language and Culture and is located in Siena, Italy.  

What I need from you

I have received a Gilman scholarship for part of the cost of the program but I need to raise $4500 more in funds. The money will be used for travel expenses to reach Siena and living expenses while there. The perks I can offer will be postcards from Italy, links to my travel blog, photos, prints of photos, personal thank you mementos, and an invitation to my presentation on my Italian adventure. I would love to share any and all my travel experiences with you! 

What if I don't meet my goal?

All of the funds donated will be used for my study abroad even if the goal of $4500 is not reached. So if you donate you are guaranteed to receive your perks.

Benefits to All 

 

In addition to sharing my travel journey with you, I have applied to share my travel experiences with a classroom of primary students in NYC. Through a program called Reach The World I can be their very own volunteer travel correspondent and they will study and learn right along with me via a travel journal, photographs and video conferencing.

This is the most exciting part of this experience for me! I want to inspire young people to follow their dreams and never feel they are limited in what they can acheive.  Plus the students will be learning interesting and educational facts about another country. 

This experience will help me craft my writing, give me hours of photo opportunities and allow me to share my own unique perspective with the world. I will also receive art instruction, journaling instruction and Italian language instruction, with credits applying toward my Bachelors in Art History. 

Thank you!

All contributions are valuable to me!  Spread the word! Use the Indiegogo share tools!

I know times are hard and believe me this is about as surreal as it gets for me, not having money for extras but going to Italy?! But I am going for it...because it feels right.

 

Thanks in advance! And don't forget to keep on dreaming!

story:
Our School

The help2kids partnership school in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania, offers a primary school education to some of the poorest children in the area. All of the 300 children who attend the school would likely otherwise be unable to attend primary school because of mandatory fees for uniforms, shoes, furniture, tests, after school subjects, watchman fee, academic contribution, identity fee, emblem fee and breakfast porridge and lunch fees. While primary education in Tanzania has been technically free since 2002, these fees make it impossible for many poor families to send their children to school.

Our Project

We aim to provide a tuition-free quality education to children from low-income families. In order to create the best learning environment for our children it is essential that each child has access to their own textbooks to study from. Keeping within our current budget for the school we were able to provide teachers with the textbooks they need to instruct classes, but still each classroom has only one text book per class for each subject. 

This campaign seeks to provide 2,840 textbooks to 300 students

  • 7 subjects for each student in Nursery to Standard 2.
  • 10 subjects for each Student in Standard 3 to Standard 7.

-The cost of each textbook is between USD $3-$7 and encompasses all subjects between Nursery and Standard 7 classes. This includes (but is not limited to): Swahili, Mathematics, Vocational Skills, Geography, History, Science, Technology, and Biology.

The Impact

A lack of textbooks is a major setback to our student’s ability to prepare for standardized testing, which is integral to their ability to continue to pursue secondary school. We employ eight teachers at our school and each displays their dedication to their job as child educators, they put in extra hours after school for English lessons, computer class to improve grade and attendance tracking and teaching workshops which we provide to help improve their skills as teachers. Our teachers all hold teaching diplomas or certificates from colleges across Tanzania and are integral in being positive role models for our children. Their dedication to the students by providing guidance, discipline, and support allows us to give them the best possible foot forward. Our teachers work very hard to uphold the best that a local education can offer, but with only one text book they are very limited.

Please help us to reach our goal of putting a textbook in every child`s hand!

Who are we 

help2kids offers parentless and other vulnerable children the opportunity for education, nutrition, and a place to live. By providing the textbooks necessary to these young children, we aim to educate the next generation and help to end the cycle of poverty.

help2kids is a Swiss based NGO and is also registered as official NGO in Tanzania with projects in Tanzania and Malawi. Our annual financial statements are online and audited from KPMG. More about us at: www.help2kids.org/orphanage.html

Contact information: Email: info@help2kids.org

story:
Brioxy It’s like having a life coach, mentor, and strategist in your back pocket


What It's All About

Well hey there! My name is Bacon and I’m part of the team here at Brioxy headquarters (well actually I’m in charge but since I’m a dog I had to get help with this campaign from people, because they have fingers). See we’re working to build a platform that helps young people of color figure out how to make their dreams possible.

This is me in my office, working really hard to bring you the best possible site we can. It’s hard working with people because they talk too much and won’t move our staff meetings to the dog park.

But this is REALLY big. It will have all kinds of tools, videos, info on things that people never tell you about—but are necessary to be successful in life, a place to manage all those darn to dos that seem to slip away from you. Things like: How do I figure out the right path to the career I want? How do I use science to build my willpower and make things happen? How do I mobilize others to help me pursue my dreams? What are the biggest social media traps? Tired of being pigeon holed around your race or gender--redefine the landscape on your terms. Authenticity and success are possible.

But to make it happen we have to get lots of folks to sign up now—give $50 to join us and help everyone start living the Brioxy life now!

What will it help us to do? 

So we need $25,000. To bring the site to everyone in 2014 we have to finish the final stage of our web design, finalize the logo/letterhead/and business cards, develop our membership welcome package (think card carrying bragging rights), take care of the legal stuff, and hit the road to introduce Brioxy to young people of color around the country. Having a tool like Brioxy in college could make all the difference. Can you say road trip!!!!!

The Impact

Many of us have big dreams for the change we want to create in our lives and the communities we come from. Making these dreams happen requires more than luck and hard work—it takes strategy. In a time of declining economic security, many organizations and companies no longer provide the pathways to developing a career that they once did. These days it often falls to you. Brioxy provides you the space and framework to organize your big dreams and access the tools and strategy that will allow you to achieve them.

Our team has over 25 years experience working in the fields of life planning, career development, and leadership development. We’ve worked everywhere—from the White House to the country's top universities. Now we want to harness it all to support you. 


Other Ways You Can Help

We’ve already invested $15,000 to get this idea off the ground. All we need now is you. Please help us spread the word and share the campaign link by clicking above to share on Facebook and Twitter. Get your membership and spread the word to help other young people of color all over the country start living the #BrioxyLife!  Thank you for your support!

story:
Our Mission

We need your help to begin activating SmartAlert™ in every school that is seeking to improve the safety of its students and faculty. Currently, millions of children are virtually unprotected should a violent threat present itself. With your help, we have the power to change that.

Our Goal

Now that we have finished the first generation of SmartAlert™, we need your help in providing necessary funds to spread the word about this incredible app. The $75,000 we seek to raise will help us achieve our goal of getting SmartAlert™ in 200 schools by the June. That would protect approximately a quarter million children and teachers who have inadequate safeguards against a violent threat on campus. The money will also enable us to add more lifesaving features to the app.

SmartAlert™ for Schools

With the push of a button on a smartphone, immediately and simultaneously notify all school personnel and the police of a present threat or emergency.

The key to minimizing violence in schools is information - - before and during an incident.  Currently, it takes the average school two to five minutes to inform all of its teachers that they must get their children behind locked doors.  SmartAlert™ is a patent pending smartphone app that reduces that time to just 15 seconds.

We need your help to get this important technology in every school in the country.

Seconds Matter in an Emergency

Time and again, survivors of school shootings say it was the simple act of hiding behind a locked door that saved them.

With SmartAlert for Schools, the amount of time elapsed from when a threat is noticed to when children are moved to a safe area is reduced from minutes to seconds.

How it Works

SmartAlert™ is simple, inexpensive and easy to use.

While we cannot stop the next accident or the next tragic occurrence, we can better prepare for it and minimize its effects. SmartAlert™ accomplishes this inexpensively, quickly, and efficiently by utilizing the device we all now possess — the cell phone.

Company Founder

Hi, I'm Michael Meinberg. I'm the founder of Mobile Alert Software, the company that makes SmartAlert™.

That's when I came up with SmartAlert™.

Thanks for taking the time to read our story and please consider contributing to the cause and passing this on to your friends, family and colleagues.

Perks

Following are the items that are included in the "Perks" you get when contributing to this campaign:

SWAG

SmartAlert for Families

story:
Teens Just Cause

"We make a living by what we get, but we make a life by what we give"  -Winston Churchill

We started Teens Just Cause to “Help those who help”. Teens Just Cause was started by Nina Nelson and Ashvita Ramesh. That's us! :-) We're Juniors at Saratoga High School and since 2013, the two of us have participated in fundraisers to benefit causes such as Project One Warm Coat and The Salvation Army. We are currently raising funds to help the Just Let Me Learn Foundation, a nonprofit organization that is helping underprivileged children get access to education. This campaign is to support their next effort to build a Girls Dorm in Saiphai, located in the northeastern mountains of India in the state of Mizoram. This campaign is extremely important as it is to help girls at risk.

Girls At Risk

On April 21, 2014 The Just Let Me Learn Foundation was thrilled to be in Saiphai to celebrate the opening of its first school! 576 children from pre-kindergarten to 10th grade started school on that day. After seven years of work, these children would finally get access to quality education. This gorgeous school at the top of a mountain became a beacon of hope for all the children in that village. 86% of the children in Saiphai and surrounding villages now attend this school. A huge accomplishment! But, there are still children in some remote villages who are unable to attend.

Just Let Me Learn Inc. is raising funds to build a girls dorm in Saiphia to house 60 girls who live too far away to attend school. In this part of India, most of the parents have very limited or no schooling. They live hand to mouth. The children in the family are a big part of surviving. Many of the kids become the heads of the house when the parents must work in the fields, sometimes for days or weeks at a time. They cook, clean and protect. If the kids have a chance to go to school, the parents need to make a choice between boys and girls. They typically pick the boys because the girls are considered property once married off into another family. Their rationale is that they should invest in the boys’ education because they will be around longer to help the family survive. Worst yet, Just Let Me Learn discovered on their last trip that many of the young girls in these villages are being targeted by sex traffickers. The traffickers entice these girls to come to the city by offering nanny and maid jobs to support their families. The parents are poor and mostly illiterate, so they are unaware of the risks. This is unimaginable considering we are in the same age group as these innocent girls. For the respect of women worldwide, and for the safety of these innocent children, this is something that needs to be stopped. We have to help Our Saiphai Sisters even in our little way! 

Our Goal

Teens Just Cause wants to fund one of the living quarters in the Saiphai Girls Dorm. It’s only one drop in the ocean, but with this single room, every single contributor will leave a reminder of the tiny but powerful difference they made in the lives of these underprivileged girls. 

Perks

We have a number of very neat perks that you can choose to help the campaign. From our $10 I Just Want to Help, to our $30 commemorative coin, to Just Let Me Learn Jackets and of course, girls dorm stuff. Select any perk that fits you!

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you may not be able to contribute cash, doesn't mean that you can't help. We would ask for you to use the Indiegogo share tools located below the video to propagate the campaign. Every tweet, +1, Facebook Like, and email sent via the .  The more eyes on the project, the  more opportunity for us to reach the "GoGo Factor". If Indiegogo sees that you have reached the GoGo factor, you will be added to their marking campaign.  The GoGo factor is  a sum total of how engaged people are with your campaign. All social media and related page view boost our Gogo Factor score. So please, share it everywhere, but make sure you are using your Indiegogo tools after you login so we can attribute referrals and donations from the seeds you planted.

story:
Holistic Nutrition Tuition

My name is Heather and I am passionate about good, clean, healthy living.  I am a holistic nutrition student at Bauman College and this program is equipping me for a career as a nutrition consultant.  I will be able to work alongside other healthcare professionals (doctors, chiropractors, counselors, etc.) to help people achieve optimal health. 

My Inspiration

My grandmother was a sharp, witty, and all around awesome woman.  When I was young she developed Type II Diabetes, and while she knew there were things she could do to improve her health; she did not exercise to speak of and would often "cheat" in her eating, causing spikes and dips in her blood sugar.  A few years ago her health began to decline and she was moved into an assisted living facility. When I got engaged, I had hoped that she would be able to come to my wedding, even if it was with the assistance of a traveling nurse.  Unfortunately, she was not healthy enough to make the trip from Southern California to the Bay Area.  In fact, she died two weeks after my wedding.  I truly believe that if she had taken better care of herself that she would still be alive today and would have been healthy enough to travel for my wedding.  I also can not help but wonder how much I could have encouraged and guided her; if I knew ten or fifteen years ago, what I'm learning now.

My Journey

Making changes to my own diet and exercise routines has had a huge impact on my energy, digestive function and mental clarity.  I want to help people to optimize their health for their own benefit as well as for the benefit of their friends and family.  

The subjects of food, health, nutrition and wellness are so big and complicated that it's no wonder people struggle with making healthy choices.  Through education and encouragement, I believe I can help my friends, family and future clients to make changes that will have a big impact on their health.  Then they can help their friends and family and we can have a ripple effect of health.

How I Got Here

I received my Bachelors in Child Development and have worked in child care for many years.  While working at a Child Care Center at Stanford, I had the opportunity to move out of the classroom and to overhaul the snack program, incorporating more fresh, organic choices.  I was also allowed to include a segment in the monthly newsletter, relating to nutrition.  This experience solidified for me that I do indeed want to study nutrition and be a resource to others in this field!

Bauman College is a vocational school, so there is no financial aid available.  I am seven months into my program and have 11 months left.  I am very excited to continue my learning, then start working with motivated individuals who want to optimize their health!

How You And I Both Benefit

I am looking to raise six thousand dollars, which is how much I still owe for school.

100% of contributions will go to my tuition.

If I don't reach my goal, the funds raised will still go to my tuition.  Every bit helps me be able to stay in school.

If by chance, contributions exceed the remainder of my tuition; I will pay off my tuition first and set aside the extra to help me when I transition out of my current job and into my new career.

As a thank you for contributing, I'm offering PERKS!

$5 - A big thank you!

$10 - A big, public, thank you on Facebook!

$25 - 5 of my favorite, tasty, healthy recipes

$50 - 10 of my favorite, tasty, healthy recipes

$100 - 10 recipes and a handmade, beaded flower

$500 - Virtual Nutrition Consultation

$1,000 - Live Nutrition Consultation

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are like me and money is an issue, there are other ways to get involved. 

Maybe you want some nutrition counseling or know someone who does?  I would love to explore the possibility of working with you. 

Maybe you are a holistically minded medical doctor, chiropractor, therapeutic masseuse, or other such health related professional and you're looking to network?  I am not only hoping to be referral based, but I am also looking for professionals from other disciplines whom I may refer clients to, and I would love to dialogue about our respective work to see if such a relationship would be mutually beneficial.

And if nothing else, please pass on the link to my campaign to anyone you know whom you think may be interested in knowing about what I'm doing.

Thank you!

If you have any questions you can e-mail me at holisticninja@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

I have lived in Kibera Community since 1990 and worked with girls since the year 2004. Kibera Girls have challenges and they trade sex for pads and panties. So many young girls only come to us when they are infected with STI's and they have none to share this secret with. 

I have finally decided to concentrate on working with women on peace and Security, but my girls still need me, the more than 800 girl in Kibera who have been used to getting their pads and panties from mum Jane must be left in style. Help prove to my girls that I care and will always be there for them.

What We Need & What You Get

I am looking for 2,500 dollars to provide adolescent girls from 11 informal schools I work with with pads and panties

Each girl will get 4 packets of pads and 4 panties enough to last them till they go back to school in January, they will be calm and focused on their education.

  • The Impact

This will reduce the number of girls trading sex for pads and panties, these are luxurious items to their needy parents most of who earn less than a dollar a day but with very large famillies.

    Risks & Challenges

    If I do not meet my target, you will all get your money back but I will not be able to assure my girls of my continuous support after moving forward to work with the women. 

    Over dependancy of girls assuming that I am the only one who can provide this for them will be managed by inviting education personnel who will understand that girls from informal schools also need pads. Linking the girls with the national campaigner for girls pads TV personnel Janet Mbugua will also create another opportunity for these girls to get pads.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      You can connect us with people and donors to help our organization grow and have financial sustainability. We focus on Child Protection, Sanitation, Education, Economic Empowerment and Sports for Peace.

story:
When: Sunday, July 26th, 2015. 10 am - 2 pm. 

Where: Rumson-Fair Haven Regional High School.

Who: Quarterbacks and receivers striving to play at the college level or simply excel at the high school level. 

Price: $75

How to register: Pay $75 by clicking the 'contribute now' button. To confirm your willingness to participate, email me at jack34wise@gmail.com. I'm excited to hear from you! 

College Football Prep

As a former wide receiver and student assistant coach at Duke, I have experienced every step of the college football experience. I learned a lot about the things coaches want to see when they recruit and the techniques and drills that make a huge difference on the field. I want to share this all with local players in an intimate and rewarding learning environment. This is something I never had access to in high school, but I really wish I did. 


What You'll Get:

-College-level QB and WR training: The drills and techniques you need to know. 
-Teaching and mentorship: We have compiled a packet of all the techniques, keys to success, and recruiting insights from our four years playing and coaching at an elite academic school. 
-Personalized feedback: a few days after our training session we will send you a document of specific things to work on. 


The Schedule:

10 am - 11:15 am: Warm-up and individual training
11:15 am - 12 pm: QB and WR together
12 pm - 1 pm: Lunch (on us). Team bonding. Review packet. 
1 pm - 1:30 pm: Individual training 
1:30 pm - 2 pm: Group work and wrap-up


About Us: 

Jack Wise lettered as a wide receiver at Duke before injuries led him to take up a role as a student assistant coach.  Jack graduated with degrees in English and Public Policy. 

"The players love Jack and were able to come to grips with difficult concepts better when he taught it because of his experience and tremendous detail." 
-Jeff Faris, Duke Wide Receivers Coach


Robert Collins lettered as a quarterback at Duke. He was coached by Duke head coach David Cutcliffe, a quarterback guru who famously coached the Manning brothers. Robert graduated with a mechanical engineering degree. 

Ryan Kirchner was a four year starter at the University of Albany. He is a three time conference champion and holder of nine school records for receiving and punt returning. Ryan also played in the Arena Football League and won the NJ CJ GR2 State Championship as a coach. Ryan graduated with a degree in English 


Duke Football -  2013 ACC Coastal Division Champions, 2013 & 2014 Top 25 BCS Ranking, 2012, 2013, & 2014 Bowl Appearances
story_txt:
When: Sunday, July 26th, 2015. 10 am - 2 pm. Where: Rumson-Fair Haven Regional High School.Who: Quarterbacks and receivers striving to play at the college level or simply excel at the high school level. Price: $75How to register: Pay $75 by clicking the 'contribute now' button. To confirm your willingness to participate, email me at jack34wise@gmail.com. I'm excited to hear from you! College Football Prep
As a former wide receiver and student assistant coach at
Duke, I have experienced every step of the college football experience. I
learned a lot about the things coaches want to see when they recruit and the
techniques and drills that make a huge difference on the field. I want to share
this all with local players in an intimate and rewarding learning environment.
This is something I never had access to in high school, but I really wish I
did. 
What You'll Get:-College-level QB and WR training: The drills and techniques you need to know. -Teaching and mentorship: We have compiled a packet of all the techniques, keys to success, and recruiting insights from our four years playing and coaching at an elite academic school. -Personalized feedback: a few days after our training session we will send you a document of specific things to work on. The Schedule:10 am - 11:15 am: Warm-up and individual training11:15 am - 12 pm: QB and WR together12 pm - 1 pm: Lunch (on us). Team bonding. Review packet. 1 pm - 1:30 pm: Individual training 1:30 pm - 2 pm: Group work and wrap-upAbout Us: Jack Wise lettered as a wide receiver at Duke before injuries led him to take up a role as a student assistant coach.  Jack graduated with degrees in English and Public Policy. "The players love Jack and were able to come to grips with difficult concepts better when he taught it because of his experience and tremendous detail." -Jeff Faris, Duke Wide Receivers CoachRobert Collins lettered as a quarterback at Duke. He was coached by Duke head coach David Cutcliffe, a quarterback guru who famously coached the Manning brothers. Robert graduated with a mechanical engineering degree. Ryan Kirchner was a four year starter at the University of Albany. He is a three time conference champion and holder of nine school records for receiving and punt returning. Ryan also played in the Arena Football League and won the NJ CJ GR2 State Championship as a coach. Ryan graduated with a degree in English Duke Football -

Ranking, 2012, 2013, & 2014 Bowl Appearances

story:
Our aim is to give tools and a community for women to understand technology and to build their ideas. We do this by providing a great experience on building things and by making technology more approachable.

We are organizing this Event for the very first time at Bogotá , Colombia. The Event is dedicated to Girls who wants to learn how to code in Ruby on Rails. 

We are expecting 30 girls and 5 coaches.So we are collecting money to provide them lunch and some snacks during the workshop

story:
We are 6 architecture students from East Los Angeles College that would like to participate in California Polytechnic State University San Luis Obispo's annual "Design Village" competition. Our names are Shanshan Bian, Rodolfo Jimenez, Michelle Lee, Nick Wu, Viviani Wang, and Ruby Kim. We are a bunch of ambitious students who share the same passion and crave more experience. With your donations, it will provide us with hand's on experience to build "shelters" in which we will inhibit for three days and two nights. Our goal to raise $1500 to help us with materials and admission. Any amount will help contribute to our mission.

Top row from the left: Nick Wu, Ruby Kim, Michelle Lee

Bottom row from the left: Shanshan Bian, Rodolpho Jimenez, Viviani Wang


4/21/2015: Thank you very much for all the support! We came back alive and well!

For more information about the competition, please go to:

http://architecture.calpoly.edu/about/Design-Village


Thank you!
Team "Mates"

story:
Short Summary

Hi! I'm Dr. Rosalyn (Roz) Dischiavo, the founder of the Institute for Sexuality Education and Enlghtenment. I opened the Institute in October of 2011 because I wanted to offer a holisitic view of sex education that was based on body, mind and spirit and focused on the whole person instead of health issues or scare tactics. I am a sexologist, meaning that I study and teach Human Sexuality for a living and I have a doctorate in Human Sexuality and a Master's degree in Marriage and Family Therapy.

I'm asking for help funding scholarships because I get calls daily from people who are very passionate about the issues. Some of them want to educate about sex and disability, sex and aging, sex and religion, sex and ehtnicity, sex and transgender issues, women's sexuality, shame issues, or what have you. One woman called because she wanted to help young war veterans who have been injured in ways that prevent the usual sexual behaviors like intercourse. She wanted them to know that they could still be sexual, still have fulfilling relationships.No one was helping them, and many of them were committing or attempting suicide until she talked to them about their alternatives. But she doesn't have enough information for them, and our program can help. I have kept her phone number, even though she doesn't know that, hoping that I could find a way to help her to help these young men.

Financially many of these people (including the woman mentioned above) cannot afford to pay for the certificate program or to garner more debt. A lot of them have just completed a master's program for counseling, or a bachelor's degree, and they are still paying those programs or loans.

Sex Education is not just important to prevent disease or unwanted pregnancy. Sex education can be a soul-opening experience where we can learn about pleasure, relationships, spirituality, ecology, gender, art, alternative lifestyles, culture, and more. People who explore their attitudes and reduce their shame about sexuality are more alive in every area of their lives.

What We Need & What You Get

As a new school, I don't have the resources for scholarships. I'd like to be able to offer a significant chunk of the tuition (which is $6600 total for the Sex Educators and $8800 for the Sex Therapy education), and I am starting with asking for $1500 so that I can help someone out. If it works well here, I will try again for another student.

If this funding works, I will ask for more for other students.

If we don't achieve our entire goal, I will put whatever we get toward individual workshops for students at $150 (one-day workshop) or $90 (half-day workshop) apiece.

We are an aweseome institute, if I do say so myself. We get into the nitty gritty aspects of sex without forgetting about the soul of sex. We help people to free their minds of prejudices and free their hearts from the burdens of needless shame. We change lives, as my students tell me all the time, by creating a safe, powerful and fun environment for people to transform their ideas, attitudes, beliefs and behaviors. We hope you can help us out!

The Impact

It may not be a popular viewpoint, but research shows that negative attitudes about sex impact women's and men's rights, birth rates, the health of children, and people's overall happiness (write me for articles, I'm big on verification of what I am saying!). Your contribution will help exponentially because you will be funding someone who teaches others. There are too many sex educators and sex therapists who focus on pathology, illness or other negativity. We need more sex educators with a sex-positive attitude who can truly talk comfortably to people about the issues that are the most sensitive and the most important to them.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help us financially, please let people know about us. You can use the indiegogo share tools to ask folks to fund us, or go to our website at www.instituteforsexuality.com or our Facebook page at https://www.facebook.com/InstituteforSEEE and see what we're about. Thanks for reading all of this, and thanks for your help!

story:
Our team of university professors, computer graphics experts, and biologists have set a goal to animate general biology textbook. 

The ideology of Muza World is centered around its purpose; “To Inspire and Motivate”.

Many students find the current system of education outdated. Our goal is to create a new educational environment that will encourage people to learn. 

Muza World revolutionizes the system of education by providing the alternative approaches to learning. All the concepts found in the general biology textbook will be covered in the animations. Information will be presented in a clear and easy to understand format. The Animations are designed to be used by a wide range of students from Secondary School through College and University levels. It will also serve as an excellent guide for preparation for medical, dental and pharmaceutical entrance exams.

The Animations will be designed and produced by an interdisciplinary team of experts in the fields of science, software engineering, and graphic designers. All are supervised by professionals with PhDs in biology and years of teaching experience.

Is animation based education more effective then the traditional? 

Yes! Scientific research suggests that using animation can increase student’s grade point average (GPA) up to 15%.

Why is learning through animations so effective? 

a) Most of us are visual learners. In other words - watching is usually more effective than simply reading or listening. A picture is worth a thousand words. Through animations, more material can be learned in less time. 

b) The Animations cater to all learning styles – auditory, visual, and verbal, among others. The students can learn the material visually and reinforce it through reading and listening, or vice-versa. Research shows that using multiple learning modules is correlated to better long-term mastery of the material.

How will students know that the animated material provided will be sufficient to do well on the exams? 

Our animations present exactly the same concepts as the most popular textbooks used at the leading educational institutions across North America. The content explained in these videos will be edited and verified by experts in the field, who will guarantee that all the essential topics are covered. 

Who is being targeted? 

Both high school and university students can use the Animations. The Animations also serve as excellent preparatory material for entrance exams to Dental, Medical, Pharmaceutical, and Veterinary schools. 

What is the mission of Muza World? 

The mission of Muza World is to give students an alternative learning method – one that is enjoyable, easy, and successful. Our goal is to help students attain the highest grade possible. 

How exactly will these animations be presented? 

You will have access to the course online, where a list of topics covered per subject will be displayed. Each topic is a link to a page with animation, text, audio, and various tools you can use to help you learn.

What languages are Muza World animations offered in?

For now, the animations are offered only in English. We are working on making our animations more accessible across the globe – we plan to animate our videos in Spanish, Russian, Cantonese, German and other popular languages in the near future. 

How long does it take to get through the Biology course? 

It would take a total of 8 hours to get through a Biology course. Yes, within 8 hours you will be able to learn the same amount of material that is taught at Universities and high schools that normally takes two semesters to learn. However we don’t recommend cramming through the course – taking breaks and going through every animation a couple of times will produce best results. 

How can I test my knowledge? 

Every video is followed with several questions that check your understanding and provides a score report. Students will also be able to test their knowledge by competing with other members. 

At Muza World we believe that education must be affordable.                

Your contribution is needed to cover the cost of producing the animation. We hope you will support this educational project. It can change lives of many students and make the process of learning much more interesting and exciting. 

Thank you for the support. We welcome you to Muza World.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Hiyam, and I am originally from Dallas, Texas.  In 2009, I decided to go back to school to get a graduate degree.  I did this because I thought it would ensure a better future for me in my chosen career--film production.  I did this because, like many Americans, I was hoping to ride out the recession, naively thinking that the economy would be vastly better by the time I graduated.  I did this because I had been told my entire life that the more education you have, the more job opportunities are available to you.

Not many of us were counting on the economy staying so difficult for so long.  I certainly wasn't.  Grad school expenses were significantly more than what government loans and scholarships were able to provide for.  In the absence of rich relatives, my only choice for continuing my education was to take out private loans.

I have now found out the hard way that private loans are much less forgiving than government loans for education.  There is no deferment option at all.  My interest rate is much higher--at almost 12%!  There are no repayment options such as income-based repayment like with government loans.  Loan consolidation is the only option.

My first private loan bill arrived just in time for Christmas for $657.  Yes, that's $657 every month for that one loan.  That does not include my government loans, which are currently in deferment.  I called my private loan lender and told them that I simply don't have the money.  They said that I am eligible to apply for for a one-time-only six-month forebearance period only after I make a good faith payment of $657, five days before Christmas.

Needless to say, I could not afford to go home for Christmas in December.  I had to borrow the money from my mother to make the payment, which has now put her in a financially difficult situation.  For many people, $657 is as much as a mortgage or rent payment.

So, that is why I have created this campaign.  I need help to pay these private loans.  Right now, I'm barely making rent and bills.

What I Need & What You Get

I need $17,500 to help me pay my loans.  In truth, this is but a fraction of the $55,000 that I owe in private loan debt, but I want my funding goal to be realistic.  $17,500 will help enormously, and it will buy me more time to get on my feet financially.

I am not the type of person to beg for money, so I want to offer my original photographic prints in return for your contribution.  I have several 'perks' listed to the right in return for your donation.  If you have any questions about the photographs before donating, please let me know.

You can choose from the photographs here: http://www.hiyamsandwich.com/5.html

The funds will all go towards my debt.  My immediate goal in life is to not go hungry and homeless.  Seriously.  That is where I'm at right now financially, and that's how much of a difference your contributions will make, so please give anything you can.  Even if I don't reach my entire goal of $17,500, it will still be of help to me.  Any amount will help.

The Impact

Your funds will help me pay my debt, plain and simple.  I just can't afford to pay an additional $657 a month when I'm not even making my rent and bills.  I am unemployed, and I continue to look for work.  The way I see it is that I am trading a good for a monetary contribution from you.  You are giving me the opportunity to produce some of my work for you, so I can hold my head up with pride instead of simply begging you for your money.

I do have a successful track record with IndieGoGo campaigns.  Last year, I raised my entire goal to make a film.  Because of those contributions, I was able to make the film and to watch it make a very successful film festival run.  My hope is that my film will help advance my career as a filmmaker.

Other Ways You Can Help

I certainly understand that not everyone can afford to contribute financially.  If you'd still like to help, you can!  Please share this campaign with all of your friends and family members.  

College loan debt has recently topped credit card debt in America.  I am amongst many recent graduates and parents who are riddled with debt, and the future looks bleak under such circumstances.  The federal government has taken some steps to help ease payments on federal government loans, however, very little has been done to help those of us with private loans, too.  In fact, Congress last year deregulated some of the legislation on private loan lenders, which is why my interest rate is allowed to be as high as 12% or more.  With no payment options available to me beyond consolidation, what am I to do?

That's why it's so important that you help me spread the word about this campaign.  I need your help today.

Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you so much for your time and your contribution!

story:
My name is Brittany and I am in the 9th grade. The summer of 2013, I have the opportunity of a lifetime to travel to Europe as a Student Ambassador. This is a very unique program, founded by Dwight Eisenhower, in order to bring more Intercultural Awareness into the lives of young people. On this trip, we will learn about the culture of the countries, take part in various activities, and much more! We will be traveling to England, France, Italy, Austria, Netherlands, Germany, Belgium, and Switzerland. 3 years ago, I traveled to England and France with the same program, and it was a life changing experience! The cost of the trip is approximately $7,000, a great expense to pay for a great opportunity!

The Mission: To bridge cultural and political borders through education and exchange, creating global citizens and making the world a better place for future generations.

 

Where will the funding go?

$7,000 - Travel Expences (I plan to raise the money bit by bit)

 

For more information on the program:

  • visit - 
    • http://peopletopeople.com/about-us

story:
(English version, scroll down)

¡Necesitamos de tu apoyo!

El Tianguis Indígena EECO necesita de tu apoyo para seguir tejiendo las redes de la Economía Solidaria por América Latina.

Por segundo año consecutivo, El Tianguis Indígena EECO, constituido por hombres y mujeres indígenas de varias culturas, es una de las organizaciones invitadas especiales para participar en la Feria Ecoturística y de Producción en su 16va. emisión.

La Feria se lleva acabo anualmente en la hermana República Dominicana. En la 15va. emisión, tuvimos la oportunidad de participar como organización invitada de honor, representados con un participante que compartió la historia y esfuerzos que el Tianguis viene realizando desde 2005 en Oaxaca, México y una pequeña muestra de las artesanías y otros productos que se ofrecen en el Tianguis.

Este año, queremos que más productores y productoras del Tianguis tengan la oportunidad de compartir sus historias y productos para honrar esta distinguida invitación. Estamos convocando a tu solidaridad para cubrir los costos de traslado y los trámites migratorios para que entre 4 y 6 miembros del Tianguis puedan representar a México en este importante evento.

Contamos con tu ayuda. Todas las donaciones son importantes ¡cada dólar es de gran ayuda! por eso, te invitamos a aportar lo que puedas y también a compartir este vínculo entre tu redes, amigos, familia y colaboradores. El reto es conseguir 5,000 USdls. Antes del 1 de octubre para cubrir el costo de los boletos de avión y los trámites de pasaporte para la mayor cantidad posible de participantes.

Si prefieres hacer un donativo directamente, deducible de impuestos en México, escríbenos a: tianguis.indigena@gmail.com

Si quieres saber más sobre la 16va. Feria Ecoturística y de Producción, visita esta página: www.fca.org.do

Si quieres saber más sobre el Tianguis Indígena EECO, A.C. visita esta página:

www.tianguisindigenaeeco.org.mx

O síguenos en Facebook

We are calling for your support!

EECO Indigenous Market (Tianguis Indígena EECO) needs your support to keep weaving connections of Solidarity Economy throughout Latin America.

For the second year in a row, EECO Indigenous Market —founded by indigenous men and women from several cultures— has been invited as a special guest to the 16th annual Ecotourism and Production Fair. The fair is hosted every year in the Dominican Republic. During the 15th edition our organization participated as the guest of honor; we were represented by one participant who traveled to Dominican Republic to share the story of the Tianguis and the work we have been doing in Oaxaca, Mexico since 2005. We were also able to send a small sample of the crafts and other products offered by the EECO Indigenous Market.

This year we want to offer this opportunity to more of the local producers that participate in the Tianguis so that they too can share their stories and products with a wider audience. We are calling for your support and solidarity to cover the airfare and passports fees for  between 4 and 6 members of the EECO Indigenous Market to travel to the Dominican Republic and represent us at this important event.

We are counting on your support. All donations are important, every dollar helps! We invite you to contribute whatever you can and also to share this link among your networks, friends, family and colleagues. The challenge is to raise $5,000 USD before October 1rst to cover plane tickets and passport fees for as many participants as possible.

If you prefer to make a direct, tax deductible donation (within in Mexico) contact us at: tianguis.indigena@gmail.com

If you want to know more about the 16th annual Ecotourism and Production Fair, visit: www.fca.org.do

If you want to know more about EECO Indigenous Market, visit: www.tianguisindigenaeeco.org.mx

Or follow us in Facebook

story:
My name is Mr. Millsap and I am a Corps Member with Teach for America. I have the absolute pleasure of teaching at Sumter Central High School in rural Alabama. I am addressing you today because I believe in one very simple truth:

Education is a Right!

If you believe this notion, then you too understand that the “Achievement Gap” is arguably the largest fundamental problem facing our country, and specifically its children, today.

At all levels of education, literacy continues to be a major factor in the widening of the achievement gap between those children who are blessed with much, and those children unlucky enough to be born into a poverty stricken environment.

Education is a Right!

No child should be denied the opportunity to get a great education just because of the geography of his/her birth.

Help me make a difference in the lives of my students. Help me give students their Right to a great education. Help me close the achievement gap, while at the same time energizing my students about the wonders of Chemistry. 

This ambitious project seeks to bring a literacy curriculum to my chemistry class. If you've never read The Disappearing Spoon, then you missed out on one of the most engaging, interesting and mind expanding texts about that boring old Periodic Table of the Elements. This national best seller brings the Periodic Table to life!

If I am able to raise the full $2000 ($1860 after processing costs) for this project, I will be able to not only bring actual books into my classroom, but the supplies needed to supplement this literacy curriculum.

Here is how it breaks down: 

Approximately $1650 of the funds will go towards the purchase of 180 books - 1 for each of my students, with a couple of extras just in case.

The remaining $210 will be used for general classroom supplies for labs and other instruction related to the chemistry curriculum. 

My school provides no budget for copy paper, much less lab supplies. Every dollar spent will have a direct impact on the lives of my students. 

Remember, Education is a Right – make a difference today!

Thank you for your consideration!

story:
Who Are We?

We are the founders of two unique career resources. The first is a free career advice blog called, CAREEREALISM. The second is a motivating job search program designed to help people find work faster. It's called CareerHMO.

Why We Need Your Help

In spite of the improvement in our unemployment rate in the U.S., there are still 23 million Americans who are out of work. Many of whom are long-term unemployed (6+ months). These individuals are struggling to pay for the necessities, like food and housing. As a result, they do not have the means to pay for cutting-edge career resources that can help them get on track to finding work faster. These people need a scholarship to a program that will give them the information, tools and coaching support needed to find a new job. They need an ally. They need you!

FACT: $100 Can Change the Life of a Long-term Unemployed Person

For every $100 raised in this campaign, we will be able to put one unemployed person in our cutting-edge job search program. They will get coaching, group support, and guidance that will help them with every aspect of their job search including, resume design, cover letter creation, LinkedIn usage, interview preparation, and much more.

To see the power of the program, meet Glenn. He joined and got a new job in 45 days!

Click here to watch his story on Youtube...

Unemployment Discrimination is at an All-time High

Studies show people who have been out of work one month or longer are discriminated against by hiring managers. Even worse, a recent survey indicates that those that have been out of work 2+ years are less likely to get hired than a convicted felon. Being unemployed in America today is mentally and emotionally difficult. Yet, you can't get hired without a good attitude - talk about a Catch 22!

Crisis of Confidence is a Major Setback to the Unemployed

If you, or someone you know has been unemployed long-term, then you can relate to the devatstating effects it has on a person's confidence. The long-term unemployed are the forgotten lost souls of our working world. Please help them find their way back to meaningful employment!

Allies to the Out-of-Work Understand the Need to Pay-it-Forward!

By contributing to this campaign, you are showing our society how important it is to help one another. These days, EVERY job is temporary. Which means, any one of us could end up unemployed. Supporting this effort shows a true understanding of the importance of paying it forward!

A Final Thought...

Thank you for taking the time to consider our campaign. The fact that you were willing to explore this concept says a lot about you! We are so glad you took the time to see what we are doing and would be grateful if you would spread the word. We also hope you'll check out all the perks we are offering with each donation and have our fingers crossed that you decide to become an Ally to the Out-of-Work.

story:
Short Summary

Hey everyone, a very near and dear individual to myself as well as a deep student of the sacred (Islamic knowledge) is currently in a financial hardship with his family and can use some assistance. Recently they had a bug issue at their place of residence which required them to throw out many of their mattresses and rent has been backlogged.


The money raised will help towards helping the student buy new mattresses and help cover some backlogged rent and other bills

What We Need & What You Get

Looking to raise:

About $3,500 of which will help fully cover some past due rent and some bills along with being able to help the family replace whatever had to be discarded during the recent bug issue.

In return you will receive duas from a thankful student as well as his family

The Impact

The Quran teaches us "Those needy ones who are wholly wrapped up in the cause of Allah, and who are hindered from moving about the earth in search of their livelihood especially deserve help. He who is unaware of their circumstances supposes them to be wealthy because of their dignified bearing, but you will know them by their countenance, although they do not go about begging of people with importunity. And whatever wealth you will spend on helping them, Allah will know of it. (2:273)"

So let's do what we can to help the individual who is a wonderful man with a huge heart and whose impact on the Muslim American community is now slowly being felt across the area. I personally know first hand how much this means to him and his family so please let us do what we can.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have questions please reach out to me and if you need more details i'd be happy to provide. Thanks so much all!

story:
Help the Lark take flight!


Update Thursday April 18th - LOOK, WE'RE ALMOST THERE!

We need LESS THAN $100 to reach the Lark's goal. We're very close! But we're also biting our nails ... because the deadline is TOMORROW. Now is the time to donate - and please share our campaign!

Help keep music in our Staten Island schools.

Every contribution helps - $5 can buy a student a practice recorder, and $150 can purchase them for a whole class. $100 may be enough to bring a sad, dusty piano back to life. The Lark Fund will work through grants. In the pilot year, COAHSI will contribute the coordination and work. This means that 100% of the money raised will go directly to local schools. Awardees will be selected by a panel of Staten Island educators, musicians, and others in the music business, after a simple application process.

Remember what a difference music made in your school day? Maybe someone from your school went on to make it big in the industry. Or maybe music was just the one class that kept a classmate coming back to school. Today's students need the same opportunities that we had, but many schools just can't afford it. And money from foundations is stretched thin.

So let's tackle this problem as a community. Please donate to the Lark.


And as a thank you, you'll receive some great perks - take a look!

story:
Short Summary

 

The most commonly reported primary substance of abuse among DUI/DWI admissions to substance abuse treatment was alcohol (90 percent). Impaired driving continues to be a severe and persistent threat to public health and safety. In 2007, an estimated 2.5 million people were injured or killed in motor vehicle accidents.1 Of these, 13,000 were deaths attributable to alcohol or drug involved vehicle crashes, and these fatalities accounted for nearly one third of all vehicular deaths in the United States. Individuals arrested for driving under the influence or driving while intoxicated (DUI/DWI) can be diverted to a treatment program either before formal judgment or after conviction as part of sentencing. DUI/DWI programs are most often conducted in an outpatient setting and can be shorter than other outpatient programs. Understanding the characteristics of DUI/DWI clients may help program designers and planners to tailor their interventions to better meet the needs of their clients.

In addition, there is a measurable relationship between alcohol and crime. According to CrimeSolutions.gov, (2013)  “alcohol also impact crime indirectly via the effects they have on users’ behavior and by their association with violence and other illegal activity in connection with their manufacture, distribution, acquisition or consumption.” Para. 1. Therefore, alcohol abuse and DWI prevention, intervention, and treatment are critical for a safer society.

The Impact

  • An average of one alcohol-impaired-driving fatality occurred every 53 minutes in 2011.
  • In 2011, 9,878 people were killed in alcohol-impaired-driving crashes. These alcohol-impaired driving fatalities accounted for 31 percent of the total motor vehicle traffic fatalities in the United States.
  • Traffic fatalities in alcohol-impaired-driving crashes decreased by 2.5 percent from 2010.
  • In 2011, a total of 1,140 children age 14 and younger were killed in motor vehicle traffic crashes. Of those 1,140 fatalities, 181 occurred in alcohol-impaired-driving crashes.
  • The rate of alcohol impairment among drivers involved in fatal crashes in 2011 was 4.5
    times higher at night than during the day.
  • In 2011, 15 percent of all drivers involved in fatal crashes during the week were alcohol-impaired, compared to 31 percent on weekends.
  • In fatal crashes in 2011 the highest percentage of drivers with a BAC level of .08 or higher was for drivers ages 21 to 24.
  • The proportion of drivers involved in fatal crashes with BAC levels of .08 or higher was 24 percent among males and 14 percent among females.
  • The percentages of drivers involved in fatal crashes with a BAC level of .08 or higher in 2011 were 29 percent for motorcycles, 24 percent for passenger cars, and 21 percent for light trucks.
  • Alcohol-related deaths in the US since 1982 (these numbers will adjust on occasion as new data arrives)

Other Ways You Can Help

Alcohol abuse and DWI awareness is a core factor in real prevention and intervention. Therefore, a comprehensive awareness campaign is critical toward making sure that everyone is fully knowledgeable of the real dangers of alcohol abuse and DWI on local, state, and national levels. The proposed awareness campaign will aim to emphasize such topics as: resistance training, knowledge of immediate effects of alcohol use, identification of the risks of alcohol misuse, and recognition of social pressures that lead to alcohol misuse and the increasing rate of DWI: especially among youths. This DWI preventive intervention program for both youths and adults is designed to help individuals make better decisions about using alcohol and driving. The program provides drug or alcohol treatment services to persistent drug and alcohol users toward improving people’s quality of life and one free from alcohol and substance abuse. The DWI program provides alcohol treatment and education, as well as case management and intensive supervision services that will assist in reducing the current DWI trends.

Prevention, intervention, and treatment does work. Rempel and colleagues (2003) found that participation in the Brooklyn Treatment Court (BTC) reduced recidivism by 27 percent after 3 years and by 18 percent after 4 years, relative to the comparison group level. For those who did recidivate at least once, the average number of days to the first re-arrest within 4 years was 524 days for BTC participants, compared to 391 days for the comparison group. With respect to specific charges, after 3 years, BTC participants were about half as likely as the comparison group to have a new felony conviction; the difference continued and remained significant at 4 years as well. BTC participants were also less likely to have a new misdemeanor and new drug conviction at both 3 and 4 years. As such, DWI rates and crime were reduced in the program servicing area.

Dr. Grange asserted, "I have seen the devastation of DWI and DUI in the inner city and nationwide. This occurrence affects the victim as well as all who are involved. With this methodology of education and safety for those who drive, it is my hope to save people by prevention and education.”

 

Take Action:

Support this new and innovative Alcohol Abuse and DWI program today! Your heartfelt support will assist us in raising funds needed to develop and continue a comprehensive marketing campaign. We seek to raise $50,000 in a short=period of time. Therefore, any and all contributions will go to serve an excellent cause of combating alcohol abuse and DWI. All funds will go directly to the development of a social media presence and the development of many other marketing tools and resources. Whether or not we reach our desired goal of raising $50,000, our commitment will continue steadfast in the fight to save lives and to reduce the high rate of DWI.

 

Since some people aren’t in a position to make a financial contribute, there are other way to assist in this important effort. Please help get the word about this important cause and program. Share this information and the opportunity to help within your network. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this message.

Thanks for your time, interest, and consideration.

Reference

Rempel, Michael, Dana Fox–Kralstein, Amanda Cissner, Robyn Cohen, Melissa Labriola, Donald Farole, Ann Bader, and Michael Magnani. 2003. The New York State Adult Drug Court Evaluation: Policies, Participants, and Impacts. New York, N.Y.: Center for Court Innovations, 157–78.
http://www.courts.state.ny.us/whatsnew/pdf/NYSAdultDrugCourtEvaluation.pdf

The DWI program provides alcohol treatment and education, as well as case management and intensive supervision services that will assist in reducing the current DWI trends.
Prevention, intervention, and treatment does work. Rempel and colleagues (2003) found that participation in the Brooklyn Treatment Court (BTC) reduced recidivism by 27 percent after 3 years and by 18 percent after 4 years, relative to the comparison group level. For those who did recidivate at least once, the average number of days to the first re-arrest within 4 years was 524 days for BTC participants, compared to 391 days for the comparison group. With respect to specific charges, after 3 years, BTC participants were about half as likely as the comparison group to have a new felony conviction; the difference continued and remained significant at 4 years as well. BTC participants were also less likely to have a new misdemeanor and new drug conviction at both 3 and 4 years. As such, DWI rates and crime were reduced in the program servicing area.
Dr. Grange asserted, "I have seen the devastation of DWI and DUI in the inner city and nationwide. This occurrence affects the victim as well as all who are involved. With this methodology of education and safety for those who drive, it is my hope to save people by prevention and education.”
 
Take Action:
Support this new and innovative Alcohol Abuse and DWI program today! Your heartfelt support will assist us in raising funds needed to develop and continue a comprehensive marketing campaign. We seek to raise $50,000 in a short=period of time. Therefore, any and all contributions will go to serve an excellent cause of combating alcohol abuse and DWI. All funds will go directly to the development of a social media presence and the development of many other marketing tools and resources. Whether or not we reach our desired goal of raising $50,000, our commitment will continue steadfast in the fight to save lives and to reduce the high rate of DWI.
 
Since some people aren’t in a position to make a financial contribute, there are other way to assist in this important effort. Please help get the word about this important cause and program. Share this information and the opportunity to help within your network. Please use the Indiegogo share tools to share this message.
Thanks for your time, interest, and consideration.
Reference
Rempel, Michael, Dana Fox–Kralstein, Amanda Cissner, Robyn Cohen, Melissa Labriola, Donald Farole, Ann Bader, and Michael Magnani. 2003. The New York State Adult Drug Court Evaluation: Policies, Participants, and Impacts. New York, N.Y.: Center for Court Innovations, 157–78.http://www.courts.state.ny.us/whatsnew/pdf/NYSAdultDrugCourtEvaluation.pdf

story:
Short Summary

Citoyen Haïti is a five-week leadership academy and summer experience for high-achieving Haitian high school students. This summer, the program will take place from June 10th – July 19th in Port Au Prince, Haïti. 

Citoyen Haïti believes in the untapped potential of Haitian youth as well as the Haitian diaspora, and seeks to inspire students with a passion for their country and a thirst for its improvement in the 21st century and beyond. We aim to do this by recruiting Haitian university and high school students to aid us in the planning of the curriculum and work with their student counterparts, as well as by:   

  • Networking students and professionals across a field of each student’s choice, with the aim of contributing toward their understanding of a potential career path and how they can take strides towards their chosen field’s improvement within Haïti, specifically.
  • Imbuing students with skills necessary for positions with clout, including but not limited to people, risk, stress, and time management, as well as public speaking and negotiation skills. 
  • Establishing, encouraging, and developing goals related to the betterment of Haiti that will be deeply and personally tied to each student. 

As our inaugural summer approaches, we hope that you will join us as we attempt to reach our objectives of promoting a strong generation of student-citizens. We anticipate that this summer will provide a platform for Haitian students and experienced professionals from both Haïti and the Yale community to develop common goals and equip students with the specific tools and practical guidance they need to drive Haitian development. 

More detailed information about the program can found on our website: www.citoyenhaiti.org

What We Need & What You Get

Citoyen Haïti cannot operate without the generous support of sponsors and benefactors. Gifts are critical to the financial health of the program and enable us to pursue a unique and interactive curriculum that will keep the students we work with engaged and safe. Giving to Citoyen shows loyalty to a program and a belief in the next generation’s capacity to make positive contributions to society.

Your donation will ensure that students are able to apply their classroom knowledge to real-world experiences through field observations and conversations with businessmen,  politicians and prominent figures within the Haitian community and diaspora. It will also provide each student with a lunch meal a day, furnish them with materials, pay for the use of their classroom facilities, and jumpstart their final projects. 

We rely on financial support from organizations and individuals like you to fund a comprehensive program that we one day hope to see replicated in other developing nations. We request your support under any of the donation gift clubs to the right. Donations above and below the leadership gift club levels are equally appreciated.

The Impact

Citoyen Haïti’s origins are deeply rooted in the conception of education as a pipeline to success: students with a solid educational foundation are more likely to achieve greater future success, especially if they acquire schooling at or beyond the secondary school level. At Citoyen Haïti, we believe that there is a third, missing component that truly determines the breadth of a student’s accomplishments: their leadership skills. In a nation like Haïti, mired with struggles ranging from natural disasters to widespread poverty, the need for student-leaders with a deep dedication to their country is a woefully under-addressed problem. Citoyen will imbue in every student that participates the means and inspiration to affect very real, very impactful change within their country on their own - and you can help!

Other Ways You Can Help

Donations above and below the leadership gift club levels are equally appreciated. Please share this information with members of your community - we couldn't possibly do this without you!! Furthermore, any in-kind donations that could help the students out in their pursuit of self-awareness and a better country - your time and advice as a guest speaker, schoolbooks, and other conventional donations - would also be appreciated!

Want to learn more about the curriculum?

Sure!

Instructor-Analysts – the teachers and mentors of the program – will work with students in one of six different task forces whose work will be reflective of a corresponding Ministry in the Haitian government (Finance and Economy; Justice and Public Service; Women’s Rights; Public Health; Education and Vocational Training; and Communications and Arts). The curriculum is best explained through its stages, outlined here for the Justice and Public Service Ministry:

Teach: From June 10th to 14th, students will be taught how to examine the Ministry of Justice and Public Security from a comparative perspective. Instructor-Analysts will give them a broad overview and understanding of different types of legal systems, including their positives and negatives, as well as their evolution and theories related to where they are more beneficial than elsewhere and why that might be. Students will also be given a comprehensive overview of the Haitian legal system, as well as general lessons in proposal writing, how to conduct field research, and how to analyze and present data collected from conducting surveys or observations. At the end of the week, students will be challenged to discuss what legal system seems to be ideal for the Haitian government.

Observe: From June 17th to June 21st, students and Instructor-Analysts will supplement their knowledge of the Justice system with actual observations. Students will be taken to the Ministry of Justice in Port Au Prince to see the Minister’s work in action. They will visit the Supreme Court of Haiti, speak to lawyers and clerks operating in the central city, observe a trial, and visit a detention center. The students will leave Port Au Prince to conduct the same observations in the surrounding countryside.

Strategize: From June 24th to July 5th, the students will, with the guidance of their Instructor-Analyst, develop solutions for issues they will highlight from their observations. This time may or may not involve travel back to a specific location or communication with a specific person as the students, or travel to a new location. Students may want to create a new legal system hybrid and are encouraged to simulate their solutions with each other or real people. Regardless of their solutions, students will be encouraged to write out research proposals for further studies (or to simply conduct them!) in order to support their theories and ideas.

Inspire: From July 8th to July 12th, students will prepare to present their combined proposals to each other and to businessmen, politicians, and prominent figures within the Haitian community and abroad. These include the Ministers of each of the aforementioned departments. Additionally, an invitation has been extended to Haiti’s current President and Prime Minister with tentative approval. The end of the program will culminate in a three-day conference period wherein the students discuss what they have learned, seen, and concluded based upon their weeks spent at Citoyen.
